Market harmonisation harmonisation harmonisation harmonisation harmonisation SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 on the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States relating to the making available on the market and supervision of explosives for civil uses WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules and procedures for economic operators regarding products subject to certain EU harmonisation legislation and establishes a framework for cooperation with them. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation covers products that are subject to the EU harmonisation legislation listed in Annex I concerning manufactured products other than food, feed, medicinal products for human and veterinary use, living plants and animals, products of human origin and products of plants and animals relating directly to their future reproduction. Scope The regulation covers products that are subject to the EU harmonisation legislation listed in Annex I concerning manufactured products other than food, feed, medicinal products for human and veterinary use, living plants and animals, products of human origin and products of plants and animals relating directly to their future reproduction. Scope The regulation covers products that are subject to the EU harmonisation legislation listed in Annex I concerning manufactured products other than food, feed, medicinal products for human and veterinary use, living plants and animals, products of human origin and products of plants and animals relating directly to their future reproduction. Summary 2:
Re retransmission of television and radio programmes Retransmission of television and radio programmes SUMMARY OF: Directive 2019/EU on the exercise of copyright and related rights relevant for the acts of communication to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, and the making available to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, in such a way that members of Authorisations obtained for the acts of communication to the public with regard to retransmission services WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to enhance cross-border access to a greater number of television and radio programmes, by facilitating the clearance of rights for the provision of online services that are ancillary to the broadcast of certain types of television and radio programmes, and for the retransmission of television and radio programmes. It also lays down rules for the transmission of television and radio programmes through the process of direct injection. KEY POINTS The directive applies to ancillary online services offered by a broadcasting organisation, which have a clear and subordinate relationship with the broadcasting organisation’s broadcasts. These services include services that give access to television and radio programmes in a strictly linear manner, simultaneously to the broadcast, and services that give access, within a defined time period after the broadcast, to television and radio programmes which have been previously broadcast by the broadcasting organisation, so-called ‘catch-up services’. The directive does not apply to any subsequent communication to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, or to any subsequent making available to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, in such a way that members of the public may access them from a place and at a time individually chosen by them, or to any subsequent reproduction of the works or other protected subject matter which are contained in the ancillary online service. The directive does not apply to any subsequent communication to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, or to any subsequent making available to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, in such a way that members of the public may access them from a place and at a time individually chosen by them, or to any subsequent reproduction of the works or other protected subject matter which are contained in the ancillary online service. FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY? It has applied since 7 June 2021. EU countries had to incorporate it into national law by 7 June 2021. KEY TERMS Retransmission: the simultaneous, unaltered and unabridged retransmission by a cable or microwave system for reception by the public of an initial transmission from another EU country, by wire or over the air, including that by satellite, of television or radio programmes intended for reception by the public, regardless of how the operator of a cable retransmission service obtains the programme-carrying signals from the broadcasting organisation for the purpose of retransmission. Retransmission: the simultaneous, unaltered and unabridged retransmission by a cable or microwave system for reception by the public of an initial transmission from another EU country, by wire or over the air, including that by satellite, of television or radio programmes intended for reception by the public, regardless of how the operator of a cable retransmission service obtains the programme-carrying signals from the broadcasting organisation for the purpose of retransmission. MAIN DOCUMENT Directive 2019/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 April 2019 on the exercise of copyright and related rights relevant for the acts of communication to the public of Summary 5:
Protecting of terrorist content on the internet Protecting of terrorist content on the internet SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/784 on the misuse of hosting services for the dissemination of terrorist content online WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules to address the misuse of hosting services for the dissemination of terrorist content online in order to guarantee the smooth functioning of the EU single market. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all hosting service providers offering services in the EU, irrespective of their place of main establishment, insofar as they disseminate information to the public. The regulation does not affect the application of Directive (EU) 2017/541 of the European Parliament and of the Council on combating terrorism and replacing Council Framework Decision 2002/475/JHA and amending Council Decisions 2009/371/JHA, 2009/934/JHA, 2009/935/JHA, 2009/936/JHA and 2009/968/JHA (OJ L 135, 24.5.2016, pp. 53). The regulation does not affect the application of Directive 2010/13/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on the coordination of certain provisions laid down by law, regulation or administrative action in Member States concerning the provision of audiovisual media services (Audiovisual Media Services Directive) (OJ L 95, 15.4.2010, pp. 1). Horizon Europe - the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation Horizon Europe - the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/764 on the specific programme implementing Horizon Europe – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to support the creation, better diffusion and transfer of high-quality and excellent knowledge and high-quality technologies in the EU, attract talent at all levels and contribute to full engagement of the EU’s talent pool, facilitate collaborative links and strengthen the impact of R&I in developing, supporting and implementing the EU. Space of the European Union (EU) Space of the European Union (EU) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 on the Union Space Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the objectives, the budget for the period 2021-2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for the implementation of the programme. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the objectives of the programme, the budget for the period 2021-2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for the implementation of the programme. It establishes the Union Space Programme (MFF) for the duration of the MFF 2021-2027. It includes additional measures to ensure efficient and autonomous access to space for the programme and to foster an innovative and competitive European space sector, upstream and downstream, to strengthen the Union’s space ecosystem and to reinforce the Union as a global player. The programme supports the procurement and aggregation of launching services for the needs of the programme and, at their request, the aggregation for EU countries and international organisations. In synergy with other EU programmes and funding schemes, and without prejudice to ESA’s activities in the area of access to space, the programme may support: adaptations, including technology development, to space launch systems which are necessary for launching satellites, including alternative technologies and innovative systems on access to space, for the implementation of the programme’s components; adaptations to the space ground infrastructure, including new developments, which are necessary for the implementation of the programme. Third countries and international organisations may have access to GOVSATCOM services provided that: they conclude an agreement, in accordance with Article 218 TFEU, laying down the terms and conditions for access to GOVSATCOM services; they comply with Article 43 of this regulation; they comply with the conditions for access to such SST services; they comply with the conditions for access to such SST services; they comply with the conditions for access to such SST services; they comply with the conditions for the acquisition of the ownership or licence rights in respect of other tangible and intangible assets necessary for the implementation of the programme. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: The EU’s Space Strategy (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 April 2018 on the Union Space Programme (OJ L 329, 27.4.2018, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 have been incorporated in the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Digital Europe Programme Digital Europe Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/881 establishing the Digital Europe Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Digital Europe Programme (the ‘Programme’) for the duration of the European Union’s (EU’s) Digital Single Market (MMF) 2021-2027. KEY POINTS The aim of the programme is to: strengthen and promote Europe’s capacities in key digital technology areas through large-scale deployment; in the private sector and in areas of public interest, to widen the diffusion and uptake of Europe’s key digital technologies, promoting the digital transformation and access to digital technologies; support the development of advanced digital skills in areas covered by the programme in order to contribute to increasing Europe’s talent pool, bridge the digital divide and foster greater professionalism, especially with regard to high performance and cloud computing, big data analytics, cybersecurity, distributed ledger technologies (e.g. blockchain), quantum technologies, robotics, AI, while taking gender balance into account. The programme aims to: strengthen and promote Europe’s capacities in key digital technology areas through large-scale deployment; in the private sector and in areas of public interest, to widen the diffusion and uptake of Europe’s key digital technologies, promoting the digital transformation and access to digital technologies; Summary 11:
European European European Maritime Single Window environment (EMSWe) European Maritime Single Window environment (EMSWe) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/005 on the European Maritime Single Window environment WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules for the provision of the information that is required for port calls between EU countries. KEY POINTS EU countries must establish a European Maritime Single Window (EMSWe) through which, in accordance with this regulation and without prejudice to Articles 7 and 11, all information necessary for the fulfilment of reporting obligations must be provided once, by means of and in compliance with the EMS Member States. EU countries must make publicly available estimated and actual arrival and departure times of ships in an electronic format harmonised at EU level, on the basis of the data submitted by declarants to the maritime national single windows. EU countries must ensure that the required information reaches the authorities in charge of the application of the legislation in question, and is limited to the needs of each of those authorities. EU countries may jointly establish a maritime single window with one or more other EU countries. EU countries which do not have maritime ports must be exempted from the obligation to develop, establish, operate and make available a maritime national single window which is set out in paragraph 1. August 2025 and an online support website for their maritime national single window with clear instructions in the official language(s) of that EU country and, where relevant, in a language that is internationally used. EU countries must make publicly available estimated and actual arrival and departure times of ships in an electronic format harmonised at EU level, on the basis of the data submitted by declarants to the maritime national single windows. EU countries must ensure that the required information reaches the authorities in charge of the application of the legislation in question, and is limited to the needs of each of those authorities. EU countries which do not have maritime ports must be exempted from the obligation to develop, establish, operate and make available a maritime national single window which is set out in paragraph 1. August 2024 and an online support website for their maritime national single window with clear instructions in the official language(s) of that EU country and, where relevant, in a language that is internationally used. EU countries must establish a common location database that contains a reference list of location codes (14) and port facility codes, as registered in the global integrated shipping information system (GISIS) of the International Maritime Organization (IMO). EU countries must establish a common hazmat database containing a list of dangerous and polluting goods that are to be notified to the maritime national single windows in accordance with Directive 2002/59/EC and IMO FAL 7, taking into consideration the relevant data elements from the IMO Conventions and codes. EU countries must designate a national authority with a clear legal mandate to act as a national coordinator for the EMSWe. The national coordinator must act as the national contact point for users and the Commission for all matters relating to the implementation of this regulation; coordinate the application of this regulation by the competent national authorities within a Member State and their cooperation; coordinate the activities aiming at ensuring the distribution of data and the connection with the relevant systems of competent authorities; monitor the application of the EMSWe, and report their findings to the Commission. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 15 August 2019. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Maritime Single Window environment (EMSWe) (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2019/005 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 June 2019 on the European Maritime Single Window environment (EMSWe) and repealing Directive 2010/65/EU (OJ L 283, 29.10.2010, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2019/005 have been incorporated in the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only.  Interoperability of electronic road toll systems in the EU Interoperability of electronic road toll systems in the EU SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/54/EU on the interoperability of electronic road toll systems in the EU WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure the interoperability of electronic road toll systems in the European Union (EU) by means of the European Electronic Toll Service (EETS), which is complementary to the national electronic toll services of the EU countries. KEY POINTS The directive does not apply to: road toll systems which are not electronic within the meaning of point 10 of Article 2; small, strictly local road toll systems for which the costs of compliance with the requirements of Article 3 to 22 would be disproportionate to the benefits. EU countries may also apply this directive to identify the owner or holder of the vehicle and the vehicle itself for notification purposes, only if all the following conditions are fulfilled: there are no other means to identify the owner or holder of the vehicle; and the notification to the owner or holder of the vehicle of the obligation to pay is a compulsory stage of the road fee payment procedure under national law. EU countries may also apply this directive to identify the owner or holder of the vehicle and the vehicle itself for notification purposes, only if all the following conditions are fulfilled: there are no other means to identify the owner or holder of the vehicle; and the notification to the owner or holder of the vehicle of the obligation to pay is a compulsory stage of the road fee payment procedure under national law. Summary 13:
European cooperation and coordination among immigration liaison officers European cooperation and coordination among immigration liaison officers SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/005 on enhancing cooperation and coordination among immigration liaison officers deployed to third countries by Member States, the Commission and Union agencies, through the creation of a European network of immigration liaison officers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules to enhance cooperation and coordination among immigration liaison officers deployed to third countries by Member States, the Commission and Union agencies, through the creation of a European network of immigration liaison officers. The regulation is without prejudice to the responsibility of Member State authorities, the Commission and Union agencies for defining the scope and assignment of tasks and reporting lines of their respective immigration liaison officers, and to the tasks of immigration liaison officers within the framework of their responsibilities under Union and national law, policies or procedures, or under special agreements concluded with the host country or international organisations. The regulation sets up a Steering Board for a European network of immigration liaison officers. The steering board is composed of one representative of each Member State, two representatives of the Commission, one representative of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, one representative of Europol and one representative of EASO. Within the framework of such networks, immigration liaison officers must: meet regularly and cooperate, where and when appropriate, with liaison officers deployed by countries other than Member States; coordinate among themselves and with relevant stakeholders regarding the provision of their capacity-building activities to authorities and other stakeholders in non-EU countries; adopt the biennial activity report, including an overview of the deployments of immigration liaison officers. Where two or more Member States jointly deploy an immigration liaison officer, those Member States may receive Union financial support pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 515/2014. The Steering Board is composed of one representative of each Member State, two representatives of the Commission, one representative of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, one representative of Europol and one representative of EASO. To that end, each Member State appoints a member of the Steering Board as well as an alternate who will represent the Member in his or her absence. The Steering Board is composed of one representative of each Member State, two representatives of the Commission, one representative of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, one representative of Europol and one representative of EASO. Where two or more Member States jointly deploy an immigration liaison officer, those Member States may receive Union financial support pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 515/2014. The Steering Board is composed of one representative of each Member State, two representatives of the Commission, one representative of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, one representative of Europol and one representative of EASO. The Steering Board is composed of one representative of each Member State, two representatives of the Commission, one representative of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, one representative of Europol and one representative of EASO. To that end, each Member State appoints a member of the Steering Board as well as an alternate who will represent the Member in his or her absence. The Steering Board is composed of one representative of each Member State, two representatives of the Commission, one representative of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, one representative of Europol and one representative of EASO. Where two or more Member States jointly deploy an immigration liaison officer, those Member States may receive Union financial support pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 515/2014. Where two or more Member States jointly deploy an immigration liaison officer, those Member States may receive Union financial support pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 515/2014. Where two or more Member States jointly deploy an immigration liaison officer, those Member States may receive Union financial support pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 515/2014. Where two or more Member States jointly deploy an immigration liaison officer, those Member States may receive Union financial support pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 515/2014. The Steering Board is composed of one representative of each Member State, two representatives of the Commission, one representative of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, one representative of Europol and one representative of EASO. To that end, each Member State appoints a member of the Steering Board as well as an alternate who will represent the Member in his or her absence. The Chair is responsible for ensuring continuity and organising the work of the Steering Board, including supporting the preparation of the biennial work programme and the report on the activities agreed are consistent and coordinated with relevant Union instruments and structures and reflect the priorities of the Union in the area of migration. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? Regulation (EU) 2019/005 has applied since 18 February 2019. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Migration (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2019/005 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 April 2019 on enhancing cooperation and coordination among immigration liaison officers deployed to third countries by Member States, the Commission and Union agencies, through the creation of a European network of immigration liaison officers (OJ L 243, 15.9.2019, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2019/005 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Energy of energy from renewable sources Promoting of energy from renewable sources SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2015/1513 on the promotion of energy from renewable sources WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It establishes a common framework for the promotion of energy from renewable sources. KEY POINTS EU countries must set national contributions to meet, collectively, the binding overall EU target set in paragraph 1 of this directive as part of their integrated national energy and climate plans in accordance with Articles 3 to 5 and 9 to 14 of Regulation (EU) 2018/1999. EU countries must ensure that their national policies, including the obligations deriving from Articles 25 to 28 of this directive, and their support schemes, are designed with due regard to the waste hierarchy as set out in Article 4 of Directive 2008/98/EC to aim to avoid undue distortive effects on the raw material markets. EU countries must ensure that their national policies, including the obligations deriving from Articles 25 to 28 of this directive, and their support schemes, are designed with due regard to the waste hierarchy as set out in Article 4 of Directive 2008/98/EC to aim to avoid undue distortive effects on the raw material markets. Radio of electronic communications networks and services Electronic of electronic communications networks and services SUMMARY OF: Directive 2014/53/EU on the use of radio spectrum for electronic communications networks and services WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It sets out the rules for the use of radio spectrum by all electronic communications networks, including the emerging self-use of radio spectrum by new types of networks consisting exclusively of autonomous systems of mobile radio equipment that is connected via wireless links without a central management or centralised network operator, and not necessarily within the exercise of any specific economic activity. KEY POINTS Scope The directive covers the use of radio spectrum by all electronic communications networks, including the emerging self-use of radio spectrum by new types of networks consisting exclusively of autonomous systems of mobile radio equipment that is connected via wireless links without a central management or centralised network operator, and not necessarily within the exercise of any specific economic activity. The directive does not cover the content of services delivered over electronic communications networks using electronic communications services, such as broadcasting content, financial services and certain information society services, and is without prejudice to measures taken at Union or national level in respect of such services, in accordance with Union law, in order to promote cultural and linguistic diversity and to ensure the defence of media pluralism. Monitoring monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption from new heavy-duty vehicles Monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption from new heavy-duty vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/858 on the approval and market surveillance of motor vehicles and their trailers, and of systems, components and separate technical units intended for such vehicles WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the requirements for the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption from new heavy-duty vehicles (Euro VI) and for reporting other information at national and EU level relevant to climate change and repealing Decision No 280/2004/EC (OJ L 282, 19.10.2016, pp. 4). KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption from new heavy-duty vehicles (Euro VI) and for reporting other information at national and EU level relevant to climate change and repealing Decision No 280/2004/EC (OJ L 165, 18.6.2013, pp. 1-12). The regulation applies to the following vehicle categories: vehicles of categories M1, M2, N1 and N2 with a reference mass that exceeds 2 610 kg and which do not fall within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council (13), and all vehicles of categories M3 and N3; vehicles of categories O3 and O4. Emergency security of gas supply in the EU Emergency security of gas supply in the EU SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 715/2009 — measures to ensure the security of gas supply in the EU WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that all the necessary measures are taken to safeguard an uninterrupted supply of gas throughout the EU, in particular to protected customers in the event of difficult climatic conditions or disruptions of the gas supply. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the measures to ensure the security of gas supply in the EU. The measures to ensure the security of gas supply must be clearly defined, transparent, proportionate, non-discriminatory and verifiable. The measures to ensure the security of gas supply must not unduly distort competition or the effective functioning of the internal market in gas and must not endanger the security of gas supply of other EU countries or of the EU. The measures to ensure the security of gas supply contained in a preventive action plan and an emergency plan must be clearly defined, transparent, proportionate, non-discriminatory and verifiable. The measures to ensure the security of gas supply contained in a preventive action plan and an emergency plan must be clearly defined, transparent, proportionate, non-discriminatory and verifiable. Energy labelling of energy-related products Ecodesign labelling of energy-related products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/438 on energy labelling WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the efficiency of energy-related products (i.e. energy-related products) placed on the European Union (EU) market or put into service. It lays down a framework for the labelling of those products and the provision of standard product information regarding energy efficiency, the consumption of energy and of other resources by products during use and supplementary information concerning products, thereby enabling customers to choose more efficient products in order to reduce their energy consumption. KEY POINTS The regulation lays down a framework that applies to energy-related products (‘products’) placed on the market or put into service. It provides for the labelling of those products and the provision of standard product information regarding energy efficiency, the consumption of energy and of other resources by products during use and supplementary information concerning products, thereby enabling customers to choose more efficient products in order to reduce their energy consumption. It aims to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data. Summary 22:
Harmon Harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) Harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1176/2011 on the prevention and correction of macroeconomic imbalances WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) at EU and national level. KEY POINTS Harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) are used in the context of the Commission’s macroeconomic imbalance procedure, as established by Regulation (EU) No 1176/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The European System of Central Banks (ESCB) uses the HICP as an index in order to measure the achievement of the ESCB’s price stability objective under Article 127(1) TFEU, which is of particular relevance for the definition and implementation of the monetary policy of the EU under Article 140 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The HICP and the HICP-CT are based on the price changes and weights of products included in the household final monetary consumption expenditure. Neither the HICP nor the HICP-CT cover transactions between households, except in the case of rentals paid by tenants to private landlords, where the latter act as market producers of services purchased by households (tenants). The OOH price index is compiled, where possible and provided that the data are available, for the 10 years preceding the entry into force of this regulation. Each year, EU countries update sub-index weights for the harmonised indices. The Commission adopts implementing acts specifying uniform conditions for the application of the ECOICOP for the purpose of the HICP and the HICP and the HICP-CT. Each year, EU countries update sub-index weights for the harmonised indices. Countervailing duty measures and multilateral remedies Countervailing duty measures and multilateral remedies SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 37/2014 on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules for the investigation of subsidised imports from non-EU countries. KEY POINTS A product is considered to be subsidised if it benefits from a countervailable subsidy. The amount of the countervailable subsidy is determined by allocating the value of the total subsidy, as appropriate, over the level of production, sales or exports of the products concerned during the investigation period for subsidisation. The amount of the countervailable subsidy is determined by allocating the value of the total subsidy, as appropriate, over the level of production, sales or exports of the products concerned during the investigation period for subsidisation. The amount of the total subsidy is determined by allocating the value of the total subsidy, as appropriate, over the level of production, sales or exports of the products concerned during the investigation period for subsidisation. The amount of the countervailable subsidy is determined by allocating the value of the total subsidy, as appropriate, over the level of production, sales or exports of the products concerned. The amount of the countervailable subsidy is determined by allocating the value of the value of the total subsidy, as well as the level of production, sales or exports of the products concerned during the investigation period for subsidisation. The amount of the countervailable subsidy is determined by allocating the value of the value of the total subsidy, as appropriate, over the level of production, sales or exports of the products concerned during the investigation period for subsidisation. The amount of the countervailable subsidy is determined by allocating the value of the value of the products concerned. The amount of the countervailable subsidy is determined by allocating the value of the total subsidy, as appropriate, over the level of production, sales or exports of the products concerned during the investigation period for subsidisation

Summary 26:
Support support for EU countries in the implementation of reforms Technical support for EU countries in the implementation of reforms SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/241 establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to promote the EU’s economic, social and territorial cohesion by supporting EU countries’ efforts to implement reforms. It sets out the general objective and specific objectives of the instrument, the budget of the instrument for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. KEY POINTS The general objective of the instrument is to promote the EU’s economic, social and territorial cohesion by supporting EU countries’ efforts to implement reforms. This is necessary to encourage investment, to increase competitiveness and to achieve sustainable economic and social convergence, resilience and recovery. This is also necessary to support EU countries’ efforts to strengthen their institutional and administrative capacity, including at regional and local level, to facilitate socially inclusive, green and digital transitions, to effectively address the challenges identified in the country-specific recommendations and to implement EU law. The specific objectives of the instrument are to: design, develop and implement reforms; prepare, amend, implement and revise recovery and resilience plans pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2021/241. These specific objectives are pursued in close cooperation with the EU countries concerned, including through exchange of good practices, processes and methodologies, stakeholder involvement, where appropriate, and a more effective and efficient human resources management. Grants may be awarded to the national authorities, the European Investment Bank group, international organisations, public or private bodies and entities legally established in: EU countries; European Free Trade Association countries which are party to the European Economic Area Agreement, in accordance with the conditions laid down therein. The co-financing rate for grants is up to 100 % of the eligible costs. Technical support may be provided with the cooperation and support of other EU countries and international organisations. Grants may also be awarded to the national authorities, the European Investment Bank group, international organisations, public or private bodies and entities legally established in: EU countries; European Free Trade Association countries which are party to the European Economic Area Agreement, in accordance with the conditions laid down therein. By 20 February 2025, the Commission shall provide simultaneously to the European Parliament and the Council, as well as to the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, an independent mid-term evaluation report on the implementation of the regulation. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘The COVID-19 crisis’ on the European Commission's website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2021/241 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 May 2017 establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility (OJ L 193, 30.7.2018, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2021/241 have been incorporated into the original document. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Rights rights of rail passengers Rights of rail passengers SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/882 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the rights of rail passengers and improve the quality and effectiveness of rail passenger services in order to help increase the share of rail transport in relation to other modes of transport. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to international and domestic rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Directive 2012/34/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council. The regulation applies to international and domestic rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Directive 2013/11/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC (OJ L 326, 11.12.2015, pp. 1-12). Scope The regulation applies to international and domestic rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Directive 2012/34/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC (OJ L 315, 3.12.2007, pp. 14-19). Scope The regulation applies to international and domestic rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Directive 2013/11/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC (OJ L 326, 11.12.2015, pp. 1-12). Pre Pre assistance for the period 2021-2027 Instrument for Pre-accession assistance for the period 2021-2027 SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 231/2014 on the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance for the period 2021-2027 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) for the period 2021-2027, the forms of EU assistance and the rules for providing such assistance. KEY POINTS The purpose of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union (EU) and to support their accession process. It is complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The purpose of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the EU and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The purpose of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The aim of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is to prepare beneficiaries for future membership of the European Union and to support their accession process. It is also complementary with the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (NDICI) established under Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (European Commission). Summary 30:
Reporting reporting of breaches of EU law Reporting of breaches of EU law SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/943 on the protection of persons reporting breaches of EU law WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to enhance the enforcement of EU law and policies in specific areas by laying down common minimum standards providing for a high level of protection of persons reporting breaches of EU law. KEY POINTS Scope The directive applies to: persons reporting breaches of EU law to relevant institutions, bodies, offices or agencies of the EU; persons reporting breaches of EU competition and State aid rules, as well as breaches relating to the internal market in relation to acts which breach the rules of corporate tax or to arrangements the purpose of which is to obtain a tax advantage that defeats the object or purpose of the applicable corporate tax law; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to relevant institutions, bodies, offices or agencies of the EU; persons reporting breaches of EU competition and State aid rules, as well as breaches relating to the internal market in relation to acts which breach the rules of corporate tax or to arrangements the purpose of which is to obtain a tax advantage that defeats the object or purpose of the applicable corporate tax law; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to relevant institutions, bodies, offices or agencies of the EU; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU employment law to employees, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; persons reporting breaches of EU law to EU breaches falling within the scope of this directive; EU countries must encourage reporting through internal reporting channels before reporting through external reporting through external reporting channels, where the breach can be addressed effectively internally and where the reporting person considers that there is no risk of retaliation. EU countries must also provide for financial assistance and support measures, including psychological support measures, provided that such acquisition or access did not constitute a self-standing criminal offence. EU countries must also provide for reporting persons who report information on breaches falling within the scope of the directive. FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY? It has applied since 17 December 2023 and had to become law in the EU countries by 17 December 2023. BACKGROUND For more information, see: EU whistleblower protection (European Commission). Summary 31:
European Border and Coast Guard Agency European Border and Coast Guard Agency SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1240 on the creation of a European network of immigration liaison officers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a European Border and Coast Guard to ensure European integrated border management at the external borders with a view to managing those borders efficiently in full compliance with fundamental rights and to increasing the efficiency of the EU return policy. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes the European Border and Coast Guard (EUROSUR) as an integrated framework for the exchange of information and for operational cooperation within the European Border and Coast Guard in order to improve situational awareness and to increase reaction capability for the purposes of border management, including the detection, prevention and combating of illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. EUROSUR is used for border checks at authorised border crossing points and for external land, sea and air border surveillance, including the monitoring, detection, identification, tracking, prevention and interception of unauthorised border crossings for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. EU countries may charge regional, local, functional or other authorities which are in a position to take operational decisions with ensuring situational awareness and reaction capability in their respective areas of competence, including the tasks and competences listed in points (c), (e) and (f) of paragraph 3. EUROSUR is used for border checks at authorised border crossing points and for external land, sea and air border surveillance, including the monitoring, detection, identification, tracking, prevention and interception of unauthorised border crossings for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. EU countries may charge regional, local, functional or other authorities which are in a position to take operational decisions with ensuring situational awareness and reaction capability in their respective areas of competence, including the tasks and competences listed in points (c), (e) and (f) of paragraph 3. EUROSUR is used for border checks at authorised border crossing points and for external land, sea and air border surveillance, including the monitoring, detection, identification, tracking, prevention and interception of unauthorised border crossings for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. EU countries may charge regional, local, functional or other authorities which are in a position to take operational decisions with ensuring situational awareness and reaction capability in their respective areas of competence, including the tasks and competences listed in points (c), (e) and (f) of paragraph 3. EUROSUR is used for border checks at authorised border crossing points and for external land, sea and air border surveillance, including the monitoring, detection, identification, tracking, prevention and interception of unauthorised border crossings for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. EUROSUR is used for border checks at authorised border crossing points and for external land, sea and air border surveillance, including the monitoring, detection, identification, tracking, prevention and interception of unauthorised border crossings for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. EU countries may charge regional, local, functional or other authorities which are in a position to take operational decisions with ensuring situational awareness and reaction capability in their respective areas of competence, including the tasks and competences listed in points (c), (e) and (f) of paragraph 3. EUROSUR is used for border checks at authorised border crossing points and for external land, sea and air border surveillance, including the monitoring, detection, identification, tracking, prevention and interception of unauthorised border crossings for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. EU countries may charge regional, local, functional or other authorities which are in a position to take operational decisions with ensuring situational awareness and reaction capability in their respective areas of competence, including the tasks and competences listed in points (c), (e) and (f) of paragraph 3. EUROSUR is used for border checks at authorised border crossing points and for external land, sea and air border surveillance, including the monitoring, detection, identification, tracking, prevention and interception of unauthorised border crossings for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to the protection and saving the lives of migrants. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Border and Coast Guard (European Commission). This consolidated version is of documentary value only. cybersecurity cybersecurity European Union (EU) cybersecurity SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/1584 on coordinated response to large-scale cybersecurity incidents and crises WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Union’s (EU) cybersecurity agency, the European Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA). KEY POINTS The regulation establishes the European Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA), a centre of expertise on cybersecurity by virtue of its independence, the scientific and technical quality of the advice and assistance it delivers, the transparency of its operating procedures, the methods of operation, and its diligence in carrying out its tasks. ENISA carries out the tasks assigned to it under this regulation for the purpose of achieving a high common level of cybersecurity across the EU, including by actively supporting EU countries, EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies in improving cybersecurity. ENISA is a centre of expertise on cybersecurity by virtue of its independence, the scientific and technical quality of the advice and assistance it delivers, the transparency of its operating procedures, the methods of operation, and its diligence in carrying out its tasks. ENISA carries out the tasks assigned to it by Union legal acts that set out measures for approximating EU State laws, regulations and administrative provisions which are related to cybersecurity. ENISA is a centre of expertise on cybersecurity by virtue of its independence, the scientific and technical quality of the advice and assistance it delivers, the transparency of its operating procedures, the methods of operation, and its diligence in carrying out its tasks. ENISA carries out the tasks assigned to it by Union legal acts that set out measures for approximating EU State laws, regulations and administrative provisions which are related to cybersecurity. ENISA is a centre of expertise on cybersecurity by virtue of its independence, the scientific and technical quality of the advice and assistance it delivers, the transparency of its operating procedures, the methods of operation, and its diligence in carrying out its tasks. ENISA is a centre of expertise on cybersecurity by virtue of its independence, the scientific and technical quality of the advice and assistance it delivers, the information it provides, the transparency of its operating procedures, the methods of operation, and its diligence in carrying out its tasks. ENISA is a centre of expertise on cybersecurity by virtue of its independence, the scientific and technical quality of the advice and assistance it delivers, the information it provides, the transparency of its operating procedures, the methods of operation, and its diligence in carrying out its tasks. EU of EU type-approvals for vehicles, systems, components and separate technical units EU of EU type-approvals for vehicles, systems, components and separate technical units SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/005 on EU type-approvals for vehicles, systems, components and separate technical units WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? European European of the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) European of the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1053/2013 — establishment of the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) to support cooperation among law enforcement authorities in the EU. It aims to: support and strengthen action by the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating serious crime affecting two or more Member States, terrorism and forms of crime which affect a common interest covered by a Union policy, as listed in Annex I; coordinate, organise and implement investigative and operational actions to support and strengthen actions by the competent authorities of the Member States, that ‘s objectives, in particular the European Cybercrime Centre; support Member States' actions in preventing and combating forms of crime listed in Annex I which are facilitated, promoted or committed using the internet, including, in cooperation with Member States, the making of referrals of internet content, by which such forms of crime are facilitated, promoted or committed, to the online service providers concerned for their voluntary consideration of the compatibility of the referred internet content with their own terms and conditions. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 13 June 2016. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) to support cooperation among law enforcement authorities in the EU. It aims to: support and strengthen action by the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating serious crime affecting two or more Member States, terrorism and forms of crime which affect a common interest covered by a Union policy, as listed in Annex I; coordinate, organise and implement investigative and operational actions to support and strengthen actions by the competent authorities of the Member States, that ‘s objectives, in particular the European Cybercrime Centre; support Member States' actions in preventing and combating forms of crime listed in Annex I which are facilitated, promoted or committed using the internet, including, in cooperation with Member States, the making of referrals of internet content, by which such forms of crime are facilitated, promoted or committed, to the online service providers concerned for their voluntary consideration of the compatibility of the referred internet content with their own terms and conditions. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) No 1053/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 May 2016 on the establishment of the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). Recovery recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs) Recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/23 on a framework for the recovery and resolution of central counterparties and amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a framework for the recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs) which are failing or likely to fail while winding up the remaining activities through normal insolvency proceedings, and to preserve financial stability and to avoid a significant adverse effect on the financial system and its ability to serve the real economy while minimising the cost to taxpayers of a CCP failure. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out measures to recover from financial distress, to maintain the critical functions of a CCP which is failing or likely to fail while winding up the remaining activities through normal insolvency proceedings, and to preserve financial stability and to avoid a significant adverse effect on the financial system and its ability to serve the real economy while minimising the cost to taxpayers of a CCP failure. The regulation also sets out a recovery plan, which must be drawn up annually and in any case after any change to its legal or organisational structure or business or financial situation which could have a material effect on those plans or otherwise necessitate a change to the plans, review, test and, where necessary, update its recovery plans. The resolution authority of the CCP must draw up and maintain a recovery plan providing for measures to be taken in the case of both default and non-default events and combinations of both, in order to restore their financial soundness, without any extraordinary public financial support, and allow them to continue to provide critical functions following a significant deterioration of their financial situation or a risk of breaching their capital and prudential requirements. The resolution authority may require the CCP to provide them with detailed records of the contracts referred to in Article 29 of Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010 and Article 54 of Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010. The resolution authority of the CCP must draw up and maintain a recovery plan providing for measures to be taken in the case of both default and non-default events and combinations of both, in order to restore their financial soundness, without any extraordinary public financial support, and allow them to continue to provide critical functions following a significant deterioration of their financial situation or a risk of breaching their capital and prudential requirements. The resolution authority may require the CCP to provide them with detailed records of the contracts referred to in Article 29 of Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010 and Article 54 of Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010. The resolution authority of the CCP must draw up and maintain a recovery plan providing for measures to be taken in the case of both default and non-default events and combinations of both, in order to restore their financial soundness, without any extraordinary public financial support, and allow them to continue to provide critical functions following a significant deterioration of their financial situation or a risk of breaching their capital and prudential requirements. The resolution authority may also take a resolution action where it considers that the CCP has applied or intends to apply recovery measures which could prevent the CCP’s failure but cause significant adverse effects to the financial system of the EU or of one of its Member States. European Year of Rail European Year of Rail SUMMARY OF: Decision (EU) 2021/2022 on the European Year of Rail WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It designates the year 2021 as the European Year of Rail (the ‘European Year’). It aims to encourage and support the efforts of the EU, Member States, regional and local authorities, and other organisations to increase the share of passengers and freight moving by rail. KEY POINTS The year 2021 will be important for the EU rail policy, since it will represent the first full year where the rules agreed under the Fourth Railway Package will be implemented throughout the EU, namely on the opening of the market of domestic passenger services, on reducing costs and administrative burden for railway undertakings operating across the EU and on providing the European Union Agency for Railways (ERA) with additional tasks that aim to lower technical barriers. The year 2021 will be important for the Union rail policy, since it will represent the first full year where the rules agreed under the Fourth Railway Package will be implemented throughout the EU, namely on the opening of the market of domestic passenger services, on reducing costs and administrative burden for railway undertakings operating across the EU and on providing the European Union Agency for Railways (ERA) with additional tasks that aim to lower technical barriers. The year 2021 will be important for the Union rail policy, since it will represent the first full year where the rules agreed under the Fourth Railway Package will be implemented throughout the EU, namely on the opening of the market of domestic passenger services, on reducing costs and administrative burden for railway undertakings operating across the EU and on providing the European Union Agency for Railways (ERA) with additional tasks that aim to lower technical barriers. The year 2021 will be important for the Union rail policy, since it will represent the first full year where the rules agreed under the Fourth Railway Package will be implemented throughout the EU, namely on the opening of the market of domestic passenger services, on reducing costs and administrative burden for railway undertakings operating across the EU and on providing the European Union Agency for Railways (ERA) with additional tasks that aim to lower technical barriers. The year 2021 will be important for the Union rail policy, since it will represent the first full year where the rules agreed under the Fourth Railway Package will be implemented throughout the EU, namely on the opening of the market of domestic passenger services, on reducing costs and administrative burden for railway undertakings operating across the EU and on providing the European Union Agency for Railways (ERA) with additional tasks that aim to lower technical barriers. European Security and Defence College (ESDC) European Security and Defence College (ESDC) SUMMARY OF: Council Decision (CFSP) 2016/2382 establishing a European Security and Defence College and repealing Decision 2013/189/CFSP WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It establishes a European Security and Defence College (ESDC) to provide training and education in the field of the EU’s Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) at European level in order to develop and promote a common understanding of CFSP and CSDP among civilian and military personnel and to identify and disseminate best practices in relation to various CFSP and CSDP, issues through its training and education activities ('ESDC training and education activities'). KEY POINTS The ESDC provides training and education in the field of the EU’s Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) in the wider context of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) at European level in order to develop and promote a common understanding of CFSP and CSDP among civilian and military personnel and to identify and disseminate best practices in relation to various CFSP and CSDP, issues through its training and education activities ('ESDC training and education activities'). The ESDC is organised as a network bringing together civilian and military institutes, colleges, academies, universities, institutions, centres of excellence and other actors dealing with security and defence policy issues within the EU as identified by Member States, as well as the European Union Institute for Security Studies (EUISS). The ESDC establishes close links with the EU institutions and relevant Union agencies, in particular with, but not limited to, the EU Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL), the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (FRONTEX), the European Defence Agency (EDA), the European Satellite Centre (EU SatCen), and the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). The ESDC has the necessary legal capacity in order to: fulfil its tasks and meet its objectives; enter into contracts and administrative arrangements necessary for its functioning including to implement staff secondments and recruit contract staff; acquire equipment, in particular teaching equipment; hold bank accounts; and be a party to legal proceedings. The ESDC has the necessary legal capacity in order to: fulfil its tasks and meet its objectives; enter into contracts and administrative arrangements necessary for its functioning, including to implement staff secondments and recruit contract staff; acquire equipment, in particular teaching equipment; hold bank accounts; and be a party to legal proceedings. The ESDC has the necessary legal capacity in order to: fulfil its tasks and meet its objectives; enter into contracts and administrative arrangements necessary for its functioning, including to implement staff secondments and recruit contract staff; acquire equipment, in particular teaching equipment; hold bank accounts; and be a party to legal proceedings. The ESDC has the necessary legal capacity in order to: fulfil its tasks and meet its objectives; enter into contracts and administrative arrangements necessary for its functioning, including to implement staff secondments and recruit contract staff; enter into contracts and administrative arrangements necessary for its functioning, including to implement staff secondments and recruit contract staff; acquire equipment, in particular teaching equipment; hold bank accounts; and be a party to legal proceedings. The ESDC has the necessary legal capacity in order to: fulfil its tasks and meet its objectives; enter into contracts and administrative arrangements necessary for its functioning, including to implement staff secondments and recruit contract staff; enter into contracts and administrative arrangements necessary for its functioning, including to implement staff secondments and recruit contract staff; acquire equipment, in particular teaching equipment; hold bank accounts; and be a party to legal proceedings. Water reuse of treated urban waste water for agricultural irrigation Safe reuse of treated urban waste water for agricultural irrigation SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1069/2009 — minimum requirements for water quality and monitoring and provisions on risk management, for the safe use of reclaimed water in the context of integrated water management WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets minimum requirements for water quality and monitoring and provisions on risk management, for the safe use of reclaimed water in the context of integrated water management. KEY POINTS Regulation (EU) No 1069/2009 lays down minimum requirements for water quality and monitoring and provisions on risk management, for the safe use of reclaimed water in the context of integrated water management. It applies whenever treated urban waste water is reused, in accordance with Article 12(1) of Directive 91/271/EEC, for agricultural irrigation. It does not preclude food business operators from obtaining the water quality required to comply with Regulation (EU) No 852/2004 using, at a subsequent stage, several water treatment options alone or in combination with non-treatment options. Regulation (EU) No 1069/2009 lays down general rules for food business operators and covers the production, processing, distribution and placing on the market of food intended for human consumption. EU-wide admission system to attract and retain highly qualified workers from non-EU countries EU-wide admission system to attract and retain highly qualified workers from non-EU countries SUMMARY OF: Directive 2014/66/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014 on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals in the framework of an intra-corporate transfer WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to facilitate the entry of highly qualified workers from non-EU countries into the European Union (EU) and to promote the mobility of those workers. It applies regardless of whether the initial purpose of residence of the non-EU national is highly qualified employment or is another purpose which then changes to the purpose of highly qualified employment. It does not apply to third-country nationals who apply to reside in a EU country as researchers in order to carry out research projects, as they fall within the scope of Directive (EU) 2016/801 of the European Parliament and of the Council. KEY POINTS The directive applies regardless of whether the initial purpose of residence of the non-EU national is highly qualified employment or is another purpose which then changes to the purpose of highly qualified employment. It does not apply to third-country nationals who apply to reside in a EU country as researchers in order to carry out research projects, as they fall within the scope of Directive (EU) 2016/801 of the European Parliament and of the Council. Asylum Asylum Asylum Asylum Asylum Asylum Asylum Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1058 establishing the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (the ‘Fund’) for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027. The aim of the Fund is to contribute to the efficient management of migration flows and to the implementation, strengthening and development of the common policy on asylum and the common immigration policy, in accordance with the relevant EU acquis and fully respecting the international obligations of the EU and the EU countries arising from the international instruments to which they are party. The Fund supports actions serving internal EU policies and is complementary to support provided under other EU instruments, in particular the external instruments, the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+), the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) and the European Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, the Internal Security Fund and the Instrument for Financial Support for Border Management and Visa Policy. ACT Regulation (EU) 2021/1058 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 July 2021 establishing the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, amending Council Decision 2008/381/EC and repealing Decisions No 573/2007/EC and No 575/2007/EC and No 575/2007/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 May 2007 establishing the European Refugee Fund for the period 2008 to 2013 as part of the General Programme ‘Solidarity and Management of Migration Flows’ and repealing Council Decision 2004/904/EC (OJ L 144, 6.6.2007, pp. 1). Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2021/1058 have been incorporated into the original document. This consolidated version is of documentary value only.
