Card-based payments and internet and mobile payments based on cards Card-based payments and internet and mobile payments based on cards SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 on card-based payments and internet and mobile payments based on cards WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for card-based payments and internet and mobile payments based on cards. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to card-based payments and internet and mobile payments based on cards in the EU, where both the payer’s payment service provider and the payee’s payment service provider are located in the EU. The regulation does not apply to: transactions with commercial cards; cash withdrawals at automatic teller machines or at the counter of a payment service provider; transactions with payment cards issued by three party payment card schemes. Europa framework for the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications Europas framework for the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications SUMMARY OF: Decision No 2241/2004/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 March 2018 on a European framework to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It sets up a European framework to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering. KEY POINTS The decision establishes a European framework to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering. Europass consists of web-based tools and relevant available information, including information to support the European dimension of guidance provided through an online platform and supported by national services intended to help users to better communicate and present skills and qualifications and to compare qualifications. The use of Europass tools for the assessment of skills and self-assessment of skills as referred to in point (c) shall not lead directly to formal recognition or the issuance of qualifications. The use of Europass tools for the assessment of skills and self-assessment of skills as referred to in point (d) shall not lead to formal recognition or the issuance of qualifications. The use of Europass supplements shall not replace original diplomas or certificates and shall not amount to formal recognition of the original diploma or certificate by competent authorities or bodies of other countries. FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY? It has applied since 23 May 2018. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Erasmus+: the Union programme for education, training, youth and sport and repealing Decisions No 1719/2006/EC, No 1720/2006/EC and No 1298/2008/EC (European Commission). Statistics statistics concerning inland waterways Transport statistics concerning inland waterways SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 on statistics concerning inland waterways WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes common rules for the production of European statistics concerning inland waterways transport. KEY POINTS Inland waterways are an important part of the EU’s transport networks and the promotion of inland waterways transport is one of the objectives of the common transport policy, both for reasons of economic efficiency and in order to reduce energy consumption and the environmental impact of transport. The regulation does not apply to: the carriage of goods by vessels of less than 50 deadweight tonnes; vessels used principally for the carriage of passengers; vessels used for ferrying purposes; vessels used solely for non-commercial purposes by port administrations and public authorities; vessels used solely for bunkering or storage; vessels not used for the carriage of goods such as fishery vessels used solely for non-commercial purposes by port administrations and public authorities; vessels used solely for bunkering or storage; vessels not used for the carriage of goods such as fishery vessels used solely for non-commercial purposes by port administrations and public authorities; vessels used solely for bunkering or storage; vessels not used for the carriage of goods such as fishery vessels used solely for non-commercial purposes by port administrations and public authorities; vessels used solely for bunkering or storage; vessels not used for the carriage of goods such as fishery vessels used solely for non-commercial purposes by port administrations and public authorities; vessels used solely for bunkering or storage; vessels not used for the carriage of goods such as fishery vessels used solely for non-commercial purposes by port administrations and public authorities; vessels used solely for bunkering or storage; vessels not used for the carriage of goods such as fishery vessels, dredgers, floating workshops, houseboats and pleasure craft. Statistics statistics at EU level Rail transport statistics at EU level SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/608 — common rules for the production of rail transport statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes common rules for the production of rail transport statistics at EU level. KEY POINTS EU countries must report statistics which relate to rail transport on their national territory. Each EU country must report statistics which relate to rail transport on its national territory. Where a railway undertaking operates in more than one EU country, the national authorities concerned must require the company to provide data separately for each country in which it operates so as to enable national statistics to be compiled. EU countries may exclude from the scope of the regulation: railway undertakings which operate entirely or mainly within industrial and similar installations, including harbours; railway undertakings which mainly provide local tourist services, such as preserved historical steam railways. Where a railway undertaking operates in more than one EU country, the national authorities concerned must require the company to provide data separately for each country in which it operates so as to enable national statistics to be compiled. Summary 49:
Visa visa requirement for nationals of non-EU countries Schengen visa requirement for nationals of non-EU countries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 539/2001 on the requirement for nationals of non-EU countries to be in possession of a visa when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down a list of non-EU countries whose nationals are required to be in possession of a visa when crossing the external borders of the EU countries and who are members of the armed forces travelling on North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) or Partnership for Peace business. KEY POINTS Nationals of non-EU countries are required to be in possession of a visa when crossing the external borders of the EU countries if the third country where they are resident and which has issued them with their travel document is a non-EU country listed in Annex I to the regulation. Nationals of non-EU countries are exempt from the requirement for stays of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period. Nationals of new non-EU countries formerly part of and stateless persons and other persons who do not hold the nationality of any country, who reside in a EU country and who are holders of a travel document issued by that EU country are exempt from the requirement. The exemption from the requirement for nationals of non-EU countries listed in Annex II to the regulation is temporarily suspended, based on relevant and objective data, in accordance with the principle of proportionality. The suspension of the exemption from the requirement for certain categories of nationals of the non-EU country concerned for a period of up to 6 months is to take effect, taking into account the available resources in the consulates of the EU countries. The suspension of the exemption from the requirement for certain categories of nationals of the non-EU country concerned for a period of up to 6 months is to take effect, taking into account the available resources in the consulates of the EU countries. The European Commission must report regularly to the European Parliament and to the Council, at least once a year, on the appropriateness of granting visa liberalisation, by the non-EU countries whose nationals have been exempted from the visa requirement when travelling to the territory of EU countries as a result of the successful conclusion of a visa liberalisation dialogue conducted between the EU and that non-EU country. The Commission must monitor the continuous compliance with the specific requirements, which are based on Article 1 and which were used to assess the appropriateness of granting visa liberalisation, by the non-EU countries whose nationals have been exempted from the visa requirement when travelling to the territory of EU countries as a result of the successful conclusion of a visa liberalisation dialogue conducted between the EU and that non-EU country. The Commission must report regularly to the European Parliament and to the Council, at least once a year, on the appropriateness of granting visa liberalisation, by the non-EU countries whose nationals have been exempted from the visa requirement when travelling to the territory of EU countries as a result of the successful conclusion of a visa liberalisation dialogue conducted between the EU and that non-EU countries. The suspension of the exemption from the requirement for certain categories of nationals of the non-EU country concerned for a period of 12 months is to take effect, taking into account the available resources in the consulates of the EU countries whose nationals have been exempted from the visa requirement when travelling to the territory of EU countries as a result of the successful conclusion of a visa liberalisation dialogue conducted between the EU and that non-EU country. The suspension of the exemption from the requirement for certain categories of nationals of the non-EU country concerned for a period of up to 6 months is to take effect, taking into account the available resources in the consulates of the EU countries whose nationals have been exempted from the visa requirement when travelling to the territory of EU countries as a result of the successful conclusion of a visa liberalisation dialogue conducted between the EU and that non-EU countries whose nationals have been exempted from the visa requirement when travelling to the territory of EU countries as a result of the successful conclusion of a visa liberalisation dialogue conducted between the EU and that non-EU countries. European of the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) European of the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 on the establishment of the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) to support and strengthen coordination and cooperation between national investigating and prosecuting authorities in relation to serious crime affecting two or more EU countries or requiring prosecution on common bases, on the basis of operations conducted and information supplied by the EU countries’ authorities and by the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). KEY POINTS Eurojust supports and strengthens coordination and cooperation between national investigating and prosecuting authorities in relation to serious crime affecting two or more EU countries or requiring prosecution on common bases, on the basis of operations conducted and information supplied by the EU countries’ authorities, by Europol, by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and by the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). It may also assist in investigations and prosecutions that only affect that EU country but which have repercussions at EU level. Conservation of bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean Conservation of bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean SUMMARY OF: Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/98 on the application by the Union of the recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the application by the Union of the recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the general rules for the application by the Union of the recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. Each year, each EU country with a bluefin tuna quota transmits to the European Commission: an annual fishing plan for the catching vessels and traps fishing bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean; an annual fishing capacity management plan ensuring that the Member State’s fishing capacity is commensurate with its allocated quota. Each year, each EU country that intends to modify the ICCAT plan for farming capacity in force shall transmit an annual farming management plan to the Commission, which shall transmit it to the ICCAT Secretariat. The maximum number of traps registered in a Member State and of fishing vessels flying the flag of a Member State that may fish for, retain on board, tranship, transport, or land bluefin tuna is limited to the number, and the total corresponding gross tonnage, of fishing vessels flying the flag of that Member State that fished for, retained on board, transhipped, transported or landed bluefin tuna from 1 January 2007 to 1 July 2008. The maximum number and the corresponding gross tonnage of fishing vessels flying the flag of a Member State engaged in bluefin tuna fishery shall be limited to the number, and the total corresponding gross tonnage, of fishing vessels flying the flag of that Member State that fished for, retained on board, transhipped, transported or landed bluefin tuna from 1 January 2007 to 1 July 2008. Cable-operated lifts and safety components Cable-operated lifts and safety components SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1025/2012 on the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States relating to lifts and safety components for cableway installations WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that new cableway installations designed to transport persons, such as funicular railways, aerial ropeways (cable cars, gondolas, chairlifts) and drag lifts, are not liable to endanger the health or safety of persons or property when properly installed, maintained and operated in accordance with their intended purpose. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to new cableway installations designed to transport persons, such as funicular railways, aerial ropeways (cable cars, gondolas, chairlifts) and drag lifts. Scope The regulation applies to new cableway installations designed to transport persons, such as funicular railways, aerial ropeways (cable cars, gondolas, chairlifts) and drag lifts. Scope The regulation applies to modifications of cableway installations requiring a new authorisation and covers subsystems and safety components which are new to the EU market when they are placed on it; that is to say, they are either new subsystems its entirety to new cableway installations, to modifications of cableway installations requiring a new authorisation and covers subsystems and safety components which are new to the EU market when they are placed on it; that is to say, they are either new subsystems and safety components made by a manufacturer established in the Union or subsystems and safety components, whether new or second-hand, imported from a third country. Scope The regulation applies to new cableway installations designed to transport persons, such as funicular railways, aerial ropeways (cable cars, gondolas, chairlifts) and drag lifts. It aims to improve the accessibility of products and services for people with disabilities in the European Union (EU). It aims to improve the accessibility of products and services for people with disabilities. Summary 56:
EU system for supply chain due diligence The EU system for supply chain due diligence The EU system for supply chain due diligence SUMMARY OF: Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/005 on the EU system for supply chain due diligence WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a Union system for supply chain due diligence* in order to curtail opportunities for armed groups and security forces to trade in tin, tantalum and tungsten, their ores, and gold. KEY POINTS Importers of minerals or metals must: adopt and clearly communicate to suppliers and the public up-to-date information on their supply chain policy for the minerals and metals potentially originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas; incorporate in their supply chain policy standards against which supply chain due diligence is to be conducted consistent with the standards set out in Annex III to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance; identify and assess the risks in their supply chain based on available third-party audit reports concerning the smelters and refiners in that chain, and, by assessing, as appropriate, the due diligence practices of those smelters and refiners; report the findings of the risk assessment to their senior management; implement a response strategy designed to prevent or mitigate adverse impacts, consistent with Annex II to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance and with the specific recommendations set out in that Guidance. EU importers of minerals or metals must make available to EU competent authorities the reports of any third-party audit carried out in accordance with Article 6 or evidence of conformity with a supply chain due diligence scheme recognised by the Commission. If there is evidence of repeated or significant cases where economic operators implementing a scheme recognised in accordance with Article 8 have failed to fulfil the requirements of this regulation, the Commission may grant the scheme owner an appropriate period of time to take remedial action. EU importers of minerals or metals must: make available to EU competent authorities the reports of any third-party audit carried out in accordance with Article 6 or evidence of conformity with a supply chain due diligence scheme recognised by the Commission; report the findings of the risk assessment to their senior management; implement a response strategy designed to prevent or mitigate adverse impacts, consistent with Annex II to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance and with the specific recommendations set out in that Guidance. EU importers of minerals or metals must: adopt and clearly communicate to suppliers and the public up-to-date information on their supply chain policy for the minerals and metals potentially originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas; incorporate in their supply chain policy standards against which supply chain due diligence is to be conducted consistent with the standards set out in Annex III to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance; identify and assess the risks in their supply chain based on available third-party audit reports concerning the smelters and refiners in that chain, and, by assessing, as appropriate, the due diligence practices of those smelters and refiners; report the findings of the risk assessment to their senior management; implement a response strategy designed to prevent or mitigate adverse impacts, consistent with Annex II to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance and with the specific recommendations set out in that Guidance. EU importers of minerals or metals must: adopt and clearly communicate to suppliers and the public up-to-date information on their supply chain policy for the minerals and metals potentially originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas; incorporate in their supply chain policy standards against which supply chain due diligence is to be conducted consistent with the standards set out in Annex III to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance; identify and assess the risks in their supply chain based on available third-party audit reports concerning the smelters and refiners in that chain, and by assessing, as appropriate, the due diligence practices of those smelters and refiners; report the findings of the risk assessment to their senior management; implement a response strategy designed to prevent or mitigate adverse impacts, consistent with Annex II to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance and with the specific recommendations set out in that Guidance. EU importers of minerals or metals must: adopt and clearly communicate to suppliers and the public up-to-date information on their supply chain policy for the minerals and metals potentially originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas; incorporate in their supply chain policy standards against which supply chain due diligence is to be conducted consistent with the standards set out in Annex III to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance; identify and assess the risks in their supply chain based on available third-party audit reports concerning the smelters and refiners in that chain, and by assessing, as appropriate, the due diligence practices of those smelters and refiners; report the findings of the risk assessment to their senior management; report to their senior management; implement a response strategy designed to prevent or mitigate adverse impacts, consistent with Annex II to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance and with the specific recommendations set out in that Guidance; report to the European Parliament and to the Council on the effects of the regulation on the ground, including on the promotion and cost of responsible sourcing of the minerals within its scope from conflict-affected and high-risk areas and on Union economic operators including SMEs, and should report to the European Parliament and to the Council. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 9 July 2017. BACKGROUND For more information, see: EU system for supply chain due diligence (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/005 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 July 2017 on the Union system for supply chain due diligence in order to curtail opportunities for armed groups and security forces to trade in minerals from conflict-affected and high-risk areas and on Union economic operators including SMEs, and on Union economic operators including SMEs, and on the basis of the Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/005 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union system for supply chain due diligence in order to curtail opportunities for armed groups and security forces to trade in minerals from conflict-affected and high-risk areas and on Union economic operators including SMEs, on the basis of the Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/005 of the Customs customs code (EU Customs Code) EU Customs code (EU Customs Code) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 182/2013 on the application of certain provisions of the customs legislation to trade in Union goods between parts of the customs territory to which the provisions of Council Directive 2006/112/EC of 28 November 2006 on the common system of value added tax and parts of that territory where those provisions do not apply, or to trade between parts where those provisions do not apply. WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the general rules and procedures applicable to goods brought into or taken out of the customs territory of the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes the EU Customs Code (the Code), which lays down the general rules and procedures applicable to goods brought into or taken out of the customs territory of the EU. The Code is based on the principles laid down in Article 290 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and is designed to ensure uniform application of customs controls, including the exchange of risk information and analysis, common risk criteria and standards, control measures and priority control areas; the determination of the tariff classification of goods; the use of the internal Union transit procedure insofar as it does not affect a proper application of the fiscal measures at stake, which apply to the trade in EU goods referred to in Article 1(3). Customs authorities are responsible for the supervision of the EU’s international trade, thereby contributing to fair and open trade, to the implementation of the external aspects of the internal market, of the common trade policy and of the other common EU policies having a bearing on trade, and to overall supply chain security. The Commission may adopt delegated acts, in accordance with Article 284, in order to determine: the specific cases where goods are to be placed under the external transit procedure in accordance with Article 226(2); the conditions for the granting of the authorisation referred to in Article 230(2); the conditions for the revocation of a favourable decision addressed to several persons other than the person who fails to fulfil an obligation imposed under that decision; the exceptional cases in which the customs authorities may defer the date on which revocation or amendment takes effect in accordance with the second subparagraph of Article 28(4). The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts, in accordance with Article 284, in order to determine: the simplifications referred to in point (a) of Article 38(2); the facilitations referred to in point (b) of Article 38(2); the more favourable treatment referred to in point (c) of Article 38(6). European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1060 laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund Plus, the Cohesion Fund, the Just Transition Fund and the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund and financial rules for those and for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, the Internal Security Fund and the Instrument for Financial Support for Border Management and Visa Policy WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund Plus, the Cohesion Fund, the Just Transition Fund and the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund and financial rules for those and for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, the Internal Security Fund and the Instrument for Financial Support for Border Management and Visa Policy. KEY POINTS The European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) supports investments in people and systems in the policy areas of employment, education and social inclusion, thereby supporting economic, territorial and social cohesion in accordance with Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The ESF+ aims to support EU countries and regions to achieve high employment levels, fair social protection and a skilled and resilient workforce ready for the future world of work, as well as inclusive and cohesive societies aiming to eradicating poverty and delivering on the principles set out in the European Pillar of Social Rights. It also contributes to relevant aspects of the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of the SDGs by eradicating extreme forms of poverty (SDG 1); promoting quality and inclusive education (SDG 4); promoting gender equality (SDG 5); promoting sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all (SDG 8); reducing inequality (SDG 10). The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of the key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the Commission communications of 10 June 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2016 entitled ‘A new Skills Agenda for Europe’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 30 September 2020 entitled ‘European Education’, of 20 June 2017, the Council adopted conclusions entitled ‘A sustainable European future: the EU response to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’. The ESF+ should contribute to the implementation of key EU initiatives and activities, in particular the financial rules on grants, prizes, procurement, indirect management, budgetary guarantees, financial assistance and the reimbursement of external experts. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? Summary 61:
European Solidarity Corps Programme European Solidarity Corps Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/2093 on the European Solidarity Corps Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Solidarity Corps Programme (the ‘Programme’) for the period 2021-2027 (the ‘2021-2027 MFF’). It aims to boost the engagement of young people and organisations in accessible and high-quality solidarity activities, primarily volunteering, as a means to strengthen cohesion, solidarity, democracy, European identity and active citizenship in the EU and beyond, addressing societal and humanitarian challenges on the ground, with a particular focus on the promotion of sustainable development, social inclusion and equal opportunities. KEY POINTS The European Solidarity Corps Programme (the ‘Programme’) aims to boost the engagement of young people and organisations in accessible and high-quality solidarity activities, primarily volunteering, as a means to strengthen cohesion, solidarity, democracy, European identity and active citizenship in the EU and beyond, addressing societal and humanitarian challenges on the ground, with a particular focus on the promotion of sustainable development, social inclusion and equal opportunities. The European Solidarity Corps Portal is a one-stop shop for both interested individuals and organisations as regards, inter alia, the registration, identification and matching of profiles and opportunities, networking and virtual exchanges, online training, language and post-activity support and other useful functions which might arise in the future. The European Solidarity Corps Portal should be continuously developed in order to ensure easy access to the programme in accordance with the standards established by Directive (EU) 2016/2102 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) is empowered, in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2017/1939, to investigate and prosecute criminal offences affecting the financial interests of the Union as provided for in Directive (EU) 2017/1371 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The financial interests of the Union are protected by proportionate measures, including measures relating to the prevention, detection, correction and investigation of irregularities, including fraud, to the recovery of funds lost, wrongly paid or incorrectly used, and, where appropriate, to the imposition of administrative penalties. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Solidarity Corps Programme (European Commission). Global Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Displaced Workers (EGF) European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Displaced Workers (EGF) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1796 on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Displaced Workers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Displaced Workers (EGF) to help displaced workers and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased in the course of major restructuring events. It supports socioeconomic transformations that are the result of globalisation and of technological and environmental changes by helping displaced workers and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased to adapt to structural change. The EGF supports socioeconomic transformations that are the result of globalisation and of technological and environmental changes by helping displaced workers and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased to adapt to structural change. The objectives of the EGF are to demonstrate solidarity and promote decent and sustainable employment in the EU by offering assistance in the case of major restructuring events, in particular those caused by challenges related to globalisation, such as changes in world trade patterns, trade disputes, significant changes in the trade relations of the EU or the composition of the internal market and financial or economic crises, as well as the transition to a low-carbon economy, or as a consequence of digitisation or automation. The EGF supports socioeconomic transformations that are the result of globalisation and of technological and environmental changes by helping displaced workers and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased to adapt to structural change. The objectives of the EGF are to demonstrate solidarity and promote decent and sustainable employment in the EU by offering assistance in the case of major restructuring events, in particular those caused by challenges related to globalisation, such as changes in world trade patterns, trade disputes, significant changes in the trade relations of the EU or the composition of the internal market and financial or economic crises, as well as the transition to a low-carbon economy, or as a consequence of digitisation or automation. The financial contribution from the EGF must be limited to what is necessary to provide temporary, one-off support for targeted beneficiaries. The financial contribution from the EGF may be made for preparatory, management, information and publicity, and control and reporting activities. If requested by the applicant country, a financial contribution from the EGF may be made for preparatory, management, information and control and reporting activities. Within 10 working days of the receipt of the complete application or, where applicable, of the translation of the application, whichever is the later, the Commission shall acknowledge receipt of the application and request from the applicant country any additional information that it requires in order to assess the application. The financial contribution from the EGF may be made for preparatory, management, information and publicity, and control and reporting activities. The financial contribution from the EGF must be limited to what is necessary to provide temporary, one-off support for targeted beneficiaries. The financial contribution from the EGF may be made for preparatory, management, information and publicity, and control and reporting activities. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (European Commission). This consolidated version is of documentary value only. EU Recovery Recovery Instrument EU Recovery Instrument SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 establishing the European Union Recovery Instrument WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis, which is beyond the control of EU countries. KEY POINTS The European Union Recovery Instrument (EU Recovery Instrument) aims to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis, which is beyond the control of EU countries. The measures are to be financed up to an amount of  750 million in 2018 prices on the basis of the empowerment provided for in Article 5 of the Own Resources Decision. It sets out a system of sanctions for enhancing the enforcement of the preventive and corrective parts of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) in the euro area. The regulation applies to EU countries whose currency is the euro. Population population and housing population and housing SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1882/2003 on population and housing WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes common rules for the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing. KEY POINTS EU countries must submit to Eurostat data on the population covering determined demographic, social and economic characteristics of persons, families and households, as well as on housing at a national, regional and local level, as set out in the Annex to the regulation. EU countries may base the statistics on different data sources, in particular on: conventional censuses; register-based censuses; a combination of conventional censuses and sample surveys; a combination of register-based censuses and sample surveys; a combination of register-based censuses and sample surveys; a combination of register-based censuses and conventional censuses; and appropriate surveys with rotating samples (rolling censuses). EU countries must ensure that the data sources and the methodology used to satisfy the requirements of this regulation meet, to the highest possible extent, the essential features of population and housing censuses. They must make continuous efforts to enhance compliance with those essential features. EU countries must provide Eurostat with final, validated and aggregated data and with metadata within 27 months of the end of the reference year. The Commission (Eurostat) must adopt a programme of the statistical data and of the metadata to be transmitted to fulfil the requirements of this regulation. EU countries must report on the extent to which the chosen data sources and methodology meet the essential features of population and housing censuses. The Commission (Eurostat) must assess the quality of the data transmitted. The Commission (Eurostat) must provide methodological recommendations designed to ensure the quality of the data and metadata produced, acknowledging, in particular, the Conference of European Statisticians Recommendations for the 2010 Censuses of Population and Housing. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 23 June 2008. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Population and Housing’ on the European Commission's website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EC) No 1882/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 February 2008 on population and housing (OJ L 284, 31.10.2003, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1882/2003 have been incorporated in the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Council Regulation (EC) No 1588/90 of 11 June 1990 on the transmission of data subject to statistical confidentiality to the Statistical Office of the European Communities and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 322/97 (OJ L 284, 31.10.1990, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. Regulation (EC) No 1588/90 of 11 June 1990 on the transmission of data subject to statistical confidentiality to the Statistical Office of the European Communities and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 322/97 (OJ L 284, 31.10.1990, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. Regulation (EC) No 1882/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 February 1997 on Community Statistics (OJ L 284, 31.10.2003, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. last update 03.05.2020

It sets out the rules governing the functioning of the European Union (EU) and its institutions. It also sets out the rules governing the transparency of the EU’s financial interests and its transparency register. Summary 69:
European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) SUMMARY OF: Decision (EU) 2018/1725 on the establishment of an independent authority, referred to as the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS), responsible for ensuring that the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, and in particular their right to data protection, with respect to the processing of personal data, are respected by the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. KEY POINTS The European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) is responsible for ensuring that the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, and in particular their right to data protection, with respect to the processing of personal data, are respected by the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. The EDPS acts in the public’s interest as an expert as well as an independent, reliable, proactive and authoritative body in the field of privacy and personal data protection. The EDPS regularly publishes its strategic priorities and an annual report. The EDPS, as a data controller, leads by example in respecting the applicable law on the protection of personal data. The EDPS must engage openly and transparently with the media and stakeholders and explain its activities to the public in a clear language. The EDPS must implement appropriate mechanisms and tools to ensure the highest level of quality management, such as internal control standards, a risk management process and the annual activity report. Cooperation The EDPS promotes cooperation among data protection supervisory authorities as well as with any other public authority whose activities may have an impact on privacy and personal data protection. Role of the European Data Protection Supervisor The European Data Protection Supervisor decides the strategic priorities of the EDPS and adopts the policy documents corresponding to the tasks and powers of the EDPS. The Director is the reporting officer for the Data Protection Officer, the Local Security Officer, the Local Information Security Officer, the Transparency Officer, the Legal Service Officer, the Ethics Officer and the Internal Control Coordinator for the tasks relating to these functions. The Director assists the EDPS to ensure consistency and overall coordination of the EDPS and on any other tasks delegated to him or her by the European Data Protection Supervisor. The EDPS may adopt the EDPS decisions on the application of the restrictions based on the EDPS internal rules implementing Article 25 of the regulation. Authorising and Accounting Officer The European Data Protection Supervisor may delegate the powers of Authorising Officer to the Director in accordance with the charter of tasks and responsibilities concerning budget and administration of the EDPS provided in accordance with Article 72(2) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The EDPS may publish the replies to consultation by institutions on their processing of personal data in full or in part, taking applicable confidentiality and information security requirements into account. Review of complaints and judicial remedies The EDPS may suspend the investigation of a complaint pending a ruling by a court or a decision of another judicial or administrative body on the same matter. If required by the circumstances of the complaint, the EDPS must disclose the identity of the complainant to the extent necessary for the proper conduct of the investigation. If required by the circumstances of the complaint, the EDPS may suspend the investigation of a complaint pending a ruling by a court or a decision of another judicial or administrative body on the same matter. The EDPS may intervene in actions brought before the Court of Justice of the European Union in accordance with Article 58(4) of the regulation, Article 43(3)(i) of Regulation (EU) 2016/794, Article 85(3)(g) of Regulation (EU) 2017/1939, and Article 40(3)(g) of Regulation (EU) 2018/1727. The EDPS may intervene in actions brought before the Court of Justice of the European Union in accordance with Article 58(4) of the regulation, Article 43(3)(i) of Regulation (EU) 2016/794, Article 85(3)(g) of Regulation (EU) 2017/1939, and Article 40(3)(g) of Regulation (EU) 2018/1727. The EDPS may take part upon invitation in an investigation by a supervisory authority or invite a supervisory authority to take part in an investigation in accordance with the legal and procedural rules applicable to the inviting party. The EDPS may engage in mutual assistance and take part in joint operations with national supervisory authorities, each acting within the scope of their respective competences as set out in the regulation and other relevant acts of Union law. The EDPS may take part upon invitation in an investigation by a supervisory authority or invite a supervisory authority to take part in an investigation in accordance with the legal and procedural rules applicable to the inviting party. FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY? It has applied since 1 March 2018. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Data Protection Supervisor (European Commission). EU system of own resources EU system of own resources SUMMARY OF: Council Decision 2014/335/EU on the system of own resources of the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It sets out rules on the allocation of own resources to the European Union (EU) in order to ensure the financing of the EU’s annual budget. KEY POINTS The decision sets out rules on the allocation of own resources to the EU in order to ensure the financing of the EU’s annual budget. The decision applies from 1 January 2021. Summary 71:
tyres tyres SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 — harmonised information on tyre parameters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a framework for the provision of harmonised information on tyre parameters through labelling to allow end-users to make an informed choice when purchasing tyres, for the purpose of increasing safety, the protection of health, and the economic and environmental efficiency of road transport, by promoting fuelefficient, long-lasting and safe tyres with low noise levels. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to C1 tyres, C2 tyres and C3 tyres that are placed on the market. It does not apply to: off-road professional tyres; tyres designed to be fitted only on vehicles registered for the first time before 1 October 1990; Ttype temporaryuse spare tyres; tyres whose speed rating is less than 80 km/h; tyres whose nominal rim diameter does not exceed 254 mm or is 635 mm or more; tyres fitted with additional devices to improve traction properties, such as studded tyres; tyres designed only to be fitted on vehicles intended exclusively for racing; secondhand tyres, unless such tyres are imported from a third country. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 May 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Fuel efficiency (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 March 2019 establishing a framework for the provision of harmonised information on tyre parameters through labelling to allow end-users to make an informed choice when purchasing tyres, for the purpose of increasing safety, the protection of health, and the economic and environmental efficiency of road transport, by promoting fuelefficient, long-lasting and safe tyres with low noise levels. Financial support for customs control equipment Instrument for financial support for customs control equipment SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/444 establishing the Customs programme for cooperation in the field of customs and repealing Regulation (EU) No 283/2014 and Decision No 541/2014/EU and repealing Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes an Instrument to provide financial support for the purchase, maintenance and upgrading of relevant and reliable state-of-the-art customs control equipment that is secure, safe and environmental-friendly, thereby helping the customs authorities act as one to protect the financial and economic interests of the EU and to protect the EU from illegal trade while facilitating legitimate business activity. KEY POINTS The Instrument supports the customs union and customs authorities in their mission to protect the financial and economic interests of the EU and its Member States, to ensure security and safety within the EU and to protect the EU from illegal trade while facilitating legitimate business activity. It may also cover expenses linked to studies, meetings of experts, information and communication actions that are related to the objectives of the Instrument, as well as expenses linked to information technology networks focusing on information processing and exchange, including corporate information technology tools and other technical and administrative assistance needed in connection with the management of the Instrument. Recipients of Union funding acknowledge the origin of those funds and ensure the visibility of the Union funding, in particular when promoting the actions and their results, by providing coherent, effective and proportionate targeted information to multiple audiences, including the media and the public. The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 14 to amend Annex II with regard to the indicators where considered necessary, as well as to supplement this regulation with provisions on the establishment of a monitoring and evaluation framework. Electricity market for electricity Electricity market for electricity SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/943 on the internal market for electricity WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure affordable, transparent energy prices and costs for consumers, a high degree of security of supply and a smooth transition towards a sustainable low-carbon energy system. It lays down key rules relating to the organisation and functioning of the EU electricity sector, in particular rules on consumer empowerment and protection, on open access to the integrated market, on third-party access to transmission and distribution infrastructure, unbundling requirements, and rules on the independence of regulatory authorities in the EU. KEY POINTS EU countries must ensure that no undue barriers exist within the internal market for electricity as regards market entry, operation and exit, without prejudice to the competence that EU countries retain in relation to non-EU countries. EU countries may apply public interventions in the price setting for the supply of electricity to energy poor or vulnerable household customers. For the purpose of a transition period to establish effective competition for electricity supply contracts between suppliers, and to achieve fully effective market-based retail pricing of electricity in accordance with paragraph 1, EU countries may apply public interventions in the price setting for the supply of electricity to household customers and to microenterprises that do not benefit from public interventions pursuant to paragraph 3. The notification must be accompanied by an explanation of why other instruments were not sufficient to achieve the objective pursued, of how the requirements set out in paragraphs 4 and 7 are fulfilled and of the effects of the notified measures on competition. The notification must also be accompanied by an explanation of why other instruments were not sufficient to achieve the objective pursued, of how the requirements set out in paragraphs 4 and 7 are fulfilled and of the effects of the notified measures on competition. By 1 January 2022 and 1 January 2025, EU countries must submit reports to the Commission every 2 years of any changes to those measures, whether or not they require a derogation environmental protection, and their possible effect on national and international competition, whether or not such measures require a derogation from this directive. FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY? It has applied since 4 July 2019 and had to become law in the EU countries by 31 December 2020. European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/695 establishing the European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking (EuroHPC) with a mission to develop, deploy, extend and maintain in the EU an integrated world-class supercomputing and data infrastructure and to develop and support a highly competitive and innovative High Performance Computing ecosystem. KEY POINTS The aim of the EuroHPC Joint Undertaking is to: develop, deploy, extend and maintain in the EU an integrated world-class supercomputing and data infrastructure and to develop and support a highly competitive and innovative High Performance Computing ecosystem; Climate-resilient Europe – the new EU strategy on adaptation to climate change Climate-resilient Europe – the new EU strategy on adaptation to climate change SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/841 on the inclusion of greenhouse gas emissions and removals from land use, land use change and forestry in the 2030 climate and energy framework, and amending Regulation (EU) No 525/2013 and Decision No 529/2013/EU WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out a framework for the irreversible and gradual reduction of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions by sources and enhancement of removals by sinks regulated in EU law. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out a binding objective of climate neutrality in the EU by 2050 in pursuit of the long-term temperature goal set out in Article 2(1) of the Paris Agreement, and provides a framework for achieving progress in pursuit of the global adaptation goal established in Article 7 of the Paris Agreement. EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. The relevant EU institutions and the EU countries must prioritise swift and predictable emission reductions and, at the same time, enhance removals by natural sinks. EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals regulated in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. The EU-wide greenhouse gas emissions and removals in EU law must be balanced within the EU at the latest by 2050, thus reducing emissions to net zero by that date, and the EU shall aim to achieve negative emissions thereafter. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 30 June 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: The European Green Deal (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2018/841 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 May 2018 on the inclusion of greenhouse gas emissions and removals from land use, land use, land use change and forestry in the 2030 climate and energy framework, and amending Regulation (EU) No 525/2013 and Decision No 529/2013/EU (OJ L 156, 19.6.2018, pp. 1). Creative Europe Programme Creative Europe Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/523 establishing the Creative Europe Programme and amending Regulation (EU) 2015/1017 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Creative Europe Programme (the ‘Programme’) for the duration of the 2021-2027 European cultural and creative sectors, in particular the audiovisual sector. The objectives of the programme are to: safeguard, develop and promote European cultural and linguistic diversity and heritage; increase the competitiveness and the economic potential of the cultural and creative sectors, in particular the audiovisual sector; support the development, production, promotion, and dissemination of European works and support for access to those works, with the objective of reaching diverse audiences within Europe and beyond, thereby adapting to new market developments and accompanying the implementation of Directive 2010/13/EU. KEY POINTS The objectives of the programme are to: safeguard, develop and promote European cultural and linguistic diversity and heritage; increase the competitiveness and the economic potential of the cultural and creative sectors, in particular the audiovisual sector; support the development, production, promotion, and dissemination of European works and support for access to those works, with the objective of reaching diverse audiences within Europe and beyond, thereby adapting to new market developments and accompanying the implementation of Directive 2010/13/EU; European European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) SUMMARY OF: Decision No 1312/2013/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 December 2013 on the Strategic Innovation Agenda of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT): the contribution of the EIT to a more innovative Europe SUMMARY WHAT DOES THIS DECISION DO? It sets out the priority fields and the strategy for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the period 2021-2027 (SIA 2021-2027). It establishes the EIT’s objectives, key actions, mode of operation, expected results and impact, as well as an estimate of the resources needed. It also reflects Regulation (EU) 2021/695, and, in particular, the key role of the EIT as part of Pillar III ‘Innovative Europe’ of Horizon Europe, and its contribution to addressing global and societal challenges, including established targets and commitments to climate objectives and the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and to Pillar I ‘Excellent Science’ and Pillar II ‘Global Challenges and European Industrial Competitiveness’ of Horizon Europe. It contributes to tackling global and societal challenges, including established targets and commitments to climate objectives and the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and to Pillar I ‘Excellent Science’ and Pillar II ‘Global Challenges and European Industrial Competitiveness’ of Horizon Europe. Macro macro-financial assistance for Ukraine Emergency macro-financial assistance for Ukraine SUMMARY OF: Decision (EU) 2020/701 on providing macro-financial assistance to enlargement and neighbourhood partners in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic Decision (EU) 2021/947 on providing macro-financial assistance to enlargement and neighbourhood partners in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION AND OF THE REGULATION? It authorises the European Commission to make macro-financial assistance of a maximum amount of  1,2 billion to Ukraine (the ‘EU’s macro-financial assistance’), with a view to supporting Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and substantive reform agenda. KEY POINTS The EU’s macro-financial assistance is based on a quantitative assessment of Ukraine’s residual external financing needs and takes into account its capacity to finance itself with its own resources, in particular the international reserves at its disposal. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as well as and where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as well as and where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic and social development. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will complement the programmes and resources provided by the IMF and the World Bank. The EU’s macro-financial assistance should support Ukraine’s commitment to values shared with the EU, including democracy, the rule of law, good governance, respect for human rights, sustainable development and poverty reduction, as well as its commitment to the principles of open, rule-based and fair trade. The EU’s macro-financial assistance should support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as well as and where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as well as and where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as well as and where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s commitment to values shared with the EU, including democracy, the rule of law, good governance, respect for human rights, sustainable development and poverty reduction, as well as its commitment to the principles of open, rule-based and fair trade. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will complement the programmes and resources provided by the IMF and the World Bank. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as well as where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as and where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as and where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as well as and where feasible, strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as and where feasible, to strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aim to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country, as and where feasible, to strengthen the structural reform agenda of Ukraine, supplementing resources made available under the IMF’s financial arrangement. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will be managed by the Commission in a manner consistent with the agreements or understandings reached between the IMF and Ukraine, and with the key principles and objectives of economic reforms set out in the Association Agreement, including the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA), agreed under the ENP. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will be made available for a period of 12 months, starting on the first day after the entry into force of the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the Commission and the Ukrainian authorities. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will contribute to covering Ukraine’s balance-of-payments needs as identified in the IMF programme. A precondition for granting the EU’s macro-financial assistance is that Ukraine respects effective democratic mechanisms, including a multi-party parliamentary system, and guarantees respect for human rights. A precondition for granting the EU’s macro-financial assistance is that Ukraine respects effective democratic mechanisms, including a multi-party parliamentary system, and the rule of law, and guarantees respect for human rights. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will be managed by the Commission in a manner consistent with the agreements or understandings reached between the IMF and Ukraine, and with the key principles and objectives of economic reforms set out in the Association Agreement, including the DCFTA, agreed under the ENP. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will be made available for a period of 12 months, starting on the first day after the entry into force of the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the Commission and the Ukrainian authorities on clearly defined economic policy and financial conditions, focusing on structural reforms and sound public finances, to which the Union’s macro-financial assistance is to be subject. A precondition for granting the EU’s macro-financial assistance will be that Ukraine respects effective democratic mechanisms, including a multi-party parliamentary system, and the rule of law, and guarantees respect for human rights. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will be made available for a period of 12 months, starting on the first day after the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the Commission and the Ukrainian authorities on clearly defined economic policy and financial conditions, focusing on structural reforms and sound public finances, to which the Union’s macro-financial assistance is to be subject. The EU’s macro-financial assistance will be made available for a period of 12 months, starting on the first day after the Memorandum of the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the Commission and the Ukrainian authorities on clearly defined economic conditions, focusing on structural reforms and sound public finances, to which the Union’s macro-financial assistance is to be subject. A precondition for granting the Union’s macro-financial assistance will be that Ukraine respects effective democratic mechanisms, including a multi-party parliamentary

EU-wide recovery plan for swordfish (Xiphias gladius) in the Mediterranean Sea Multiannual recovery plan for swordfish (Xiphias gladius) in the Mediterranean Sea SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/005 — general rules for the implementation by the EU of a multiannual recovery plan for swordfish (Xiphias gladius) in the Mediterranean Sea WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down general rules for the implementation by the EU of a multiannual recovery plan for swordfish (Xiphias gladius) in the Mediterranean Sea starting from 2017 and continuing until 2031. KEY POINTS EU countries must take the necessary measures to ensure that the fishing effort of fishing vessels flying their flag is commensurate with the fishing opportunities for Mediterranean swordfish available to them. EU countries must limit by fishing gear type the number of fishing vessels flying their flag and authorised to catch swordfish to the average yearly number of vessels flying their flag that fished for, retained on board, transhipped, transported or landed Mediterranean swordfish during the period 2013-2016. EU countries must limit by fishing gear type the number of fishing vessels flying their flag and authorised to catch swordfish to the average yearly number of vessels flying their flag that fished for, retained on board, transhipped, transported or landed Mediterranean swordfish during the period 2013-2016. EU countries must submit their annual fishing plans to the European Commission by 1 March each year. EU countries must limit by fishing gear type the number of fishing vessels flying their flag and authorised to catch swordfish to the average yearly number of vessels flying their flag that fished for, retained on board, transhipped, transported or landed swordfish during the period 2013-2016. EU countries must limit by fishing gear type the number of fishing vessels flying their flag and authorised to catch swordfish to the average yearly number of vessels flying their flag that fished for, retained on board, transhipped, transported or landed swordfish during the period 2013-2016. Multi multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 to 2020 Multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 to 2020 SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 — the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 to 2020 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 to 2020 (MFF) for the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 to 2020 (MFF) is set out in the annex to Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund covered by the Common Strategic Framework and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1083/2006 (See page 320 of this Official Journal). The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission jointly examine the most suitable duration for the subsequent MFF before the Commission presents its proposals with a view to striking the right balance between the duration of the respective terms of office of the members of the European Parliament and the European Commission - and the need for stability for programming cycles and investment predictability. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agree to jointly examine the most suitable duration for the subsequent MFF before the Commission presents its proposals with a view to striking the right balance between the duration of the respective terms of office of the members of the European Parliament and the European Commission - and the need for stability for programming cycles and investment predictability. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission jointly examine the most suitable duration for the subsequent MFF before the Commission presents its proposals with a view to striking the right balance between the duration of the respective terms of office of the members of the European Parliament and the European Commission - and the need for stability for programming cycles and investment predictability. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission jointly examine the most suitable duration for the subsequent MFF before the Commission presents its proposals with a view to striking the right balance between the duration of the respective terms of office of the European Parliament and the European Commission - and the need for stability for programming cycles and investment predictability.
