Summary 84:
European of the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) European of the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1046 laying down the priorities of the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the priorities of the EMFAF, its budget and the specific rules for providing EU funding, complementing the general rules applicable to the EMFAF under Regulation (EU) 2021/1060. KEY POINTS The European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) supports the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), the EU’s maritime policy and the Union’s international commitments in the field of ocean governance. The EMFAF supports the following priorities: fostering sustainable fisheries and the restoration and conservation of aquatic biological resources; fostering sustainable aquaculture activities, and processing and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products, thus contributing to food security in the EU; enabling a sustainable blue economy in coastal, island and inland areas, and fostering the development of fishing and aquaculture communities; strengthening international ocean governance and enabling seas and oceans to be safe, secure, clean and sustainably managed. The EMFAF supports the following priorities: fostering sustainable fisheries and the restoration and conservation of aquatic biological resources; fostering sustainable aquaculture activities, and processing and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products, thus contributing to food security in the EU; enabling a sustainable blue economy in coastal, island and inland areas, and fostering the development of fishing and aquaculture communities; strengthening international ocean governance and enabling seas and oceans to be safe, secure, clean and sustainably managed. EU countries must prepare a single programme to implement the priorities set out in the regulation (the ‘programme’). Each EU country concerned must allocate within its Union financial support set out in Annex V, at least:  102 000 000 for the Azores and Madeira;  82 000 for the Canary Islands;  131 000 for Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte, Réunion and Saint-Martin. EU countries with no access to EU waters may apply a lower percentage with regard to the extent of their control and data collection tasks. The amount may be used for technical and administrative assistance for the implementation of the EMFAF, such as preparatory, monitoring, control, audit and evaluation activities, including corporate information technology systems. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: EMFAF (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2018/1046 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2018 laying down the priorities of the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027. Summary 85:
Fishing of tropical tunas Fishing of tropical tunas SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/2403 on the sustainable management of external fishing fleets WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable use of the fishing resources in the area covered by the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the Agreement for the Implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to EU fishing vessels used or intended for use for the purposes of fishing in the area covered by the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the Agreement for the Implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. EU countries must: inform the European Commission by 15 June each year of which of the two closure periods from 29 July to 8 October, or from 9 November to 19 January, shall be applicable to their vessels; inform all interested parties in their tuna industry of the November to 19 January, shall be applicable to their vessels; ensure that for the entire duration of the closure all purse seine vessels that fly its flag do not fish in the Convention area. Fishing on data buoys EU fishing vessels must: report daily information on all active fish-aggregating devices (FADs) to the European Commission at intervals submitted with a time delay of at least 60 days, but with a time interval of not more than 90 days between each report; collect and report any interaction with FADs to EU countries; report daily information on all active FADs to the Commission at intervals submitted with a time delay of at least 60 days, but with a time interval of not more than 90 days between each report; limit bycatch of silky sharks to a maximum of 20 % of the total catch by fishing trip in weight; promptly release sharks (whether alive or dead) caught that are not retained unharmed, to the extent practicable, as soon as they are seen in the net or on the deck, without compromising the safety of any persons. The master of a purse seine vessel must: avoid encirclement of sea turtles to the extent practicable and carry on board, and bycatch in all gear types used in the eastern Pacific Ocean; promptly release, in a manner that causes the least harm to the extent practicable, all sea turtles, without compromising the safety of any persons. EU countries must support research and development of modified FAD designs to reduce sea turtle entanglement as well as take measures to encourage the use of designs found to be successful at such reduction. The master of a purse seine vessel must: carry on-board and, when sea turtle interactions occur, employ the necessary equipment (e.g. de-hookers, line cutters, and scoop nets) for the prompt release of sea turtles incidentally caught; when the majority of hooks fish at depths shallower than 100 metres, employ one of the following two mitigation measures: large circle hooks or the use only of finfish for bait; report any interactions to the national authorities. The master of a purse seine vessel must: avoid encirclement of sea turtles to the extent practicable and carry on board, and bycatch in all gear types used in the eastern Pacific Ocean; promptly release, in a manner that causes the least harm to the extent practicable, all sea turtles, without compromising the safety of any persons. The master of a purse seine vessel must: carry on-board and, when sea turtle interactions occur, employ the necessary equipment (e.g. de-hookers, line cutters, and scoop nets) for the prompt release of sea turtles incidentally caught; when the majority of hooks fish at depths shallower than 100 metres, employ one of the following two mitigation measures: large circle hooks or the use only of finfish for bait; report any interactions to the national authorities. The master of a purse seine vessel must: avoid encirclement of sea turtles to the extent practicable and carry on board, and bycatch in all gear types used in the eastern Pacific Ocean; promptly release, in a manner that causes the least harm to the extent practicable, all sea turtles, without compromising the safety of any persons. The master of a purse seine vessel must: carry on-board and, when sea turtle interactions occur, employ the necessary equipment (e.g. de-hookers, line cutters, and scoop nets) for the prompt release of sea turtles incidentally caught; when the majority of hooks fish at depths shallower than 100 metres, employ one of the following two mitigation measures: large circle hooks or the use only of finfish for bait; report any interactions to the national authorities. The master of a purse seine vessel must: avoid encirclement of sea turtles to the extent practicable and carry on board, and bycatch in all gear types used in the eastern Pacific Ocean. The master of a purse seine vessel must: carry on-board and, when sea turtle interactions occur, employ the necessary equipment (e.g. de-hookers, line cutters, and scoop nets) for the prompt release of sea turtles incidentally caught; when the majority of hooks fish at depths shallower than 100 metres, employ one of the following two mitigation measures: large circle hooks or the use only of finfish for bait; report any interactions to the national authorities. The master of a purse seine vessel must: carry on-board and, when sea turtle interactions occur, employ the necessary equipment (e.g. de-hookers, line cutters, and scoop nets) for the prompt release of sea turtles incidentally caught; when the majority of hooks fish at depths shallower than 100 metres, employ one of the following two mitigation measures: large circle hooks or the use only of finfish for bait; report any interactions to the national authorities. The master of a purse seine vessel must: avoid encirclement of sea turtles to the extent practicable and carry on board, and bycatch in all gear types used in the eastern Pacific Ocean. The master of a purse seine vessel must: carry on-board and, when sea turtle interactions occur, employ the necessary equipment (e.g. de-hookers, line cutters, and scoop nets) for the prompt release of sea turtles incidentally caught; when the majority of hooks fish at depths shallower than 100 metres, employ one of the following two mitigation measures: large circle hooks or the use only of finfish for bait; report any interactions to the national authorities. The master of a purse seine vessel must: avoid encirclement of sea turtles to the extent practicable and carry on board, and bycatch in all gear types used in the eastern Pacific Ocean. The master of a purse seine vessel must: carry on-board and, when sea turtle interactions occur, employ the necessary equipment (e.g. de-hookers, line cutters, line cutters, and scoop nets) for the prompt release of sea turtles incidentally caught; when the majority of hooks fish at depths shallower than 100 metres, employ one of the following two mitigation measures: large circle hooks or the use only of finfish for bait; report any interactions to the national authorities. The master of a purse seine vessel must: promptly release, in a manner that causes the least harm to the extent practicable, all sea turtles, without compromising the safety of any persons. EU countries must support research and development of modified FAD designs to reduce sea turtle entanglement as well as take measures to encourage the use of designs found to be successful at such reduction. Citizens Citizens Citizens Citizens’ initiative EU Citizens’ initiative SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1151/2011 — procedures and conditions for supporting a citizens’ initiative WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the procedures and conditions for supporting a citizens’ initiative*. It sets out the minimum number of signatories required in each EU country to support a citizens’ initiative*. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation sets out the procedures and conditions for supporting a citizens’ initiative*. It sets out the minimum number of signatories required in each EU country to support a citizens’ initiative*. It also sets out the procedure for the examination of a citizens’ initiative by the European Commission. Statistics statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides Pesticide statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 on European statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common framework for the systematic production of EU statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides which are plant protection products. KEY POINTS EU countries must collect the data necessary for the specification of the characteristics listed in Annex I on an annual basis and for the specification of the characteristics listed in Annex II in five-year periods by means of: surveys, information concerning the placing on the market and use of pesticides taking into account, in particular, the obligations pursuant to Article 67 of Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009, administrative sources, or, a combination of these means, including statistical estimation procedures on the basis of expert judgements or models. EU countries must collect the data necessary for the specification of the characteristics listed in Annex I on an annual basis and for the specification of the characteristics listed in Annex II in five-year periods by means of: surveys, information concerning the placing on the market and use of pesticides taking into account, in particular, the obligations pursuant to Article 67 of Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009, administrative sources, or, a combination of these means, including statistical estimation procedures on the basis of expert judgements or models. The Commission must adapt the list of substances to be covered and their classification in categories of products and chemical classes as set out in Annex III on a regular basis and at least every 5 years. The Commission may, if necessary, modify requirements relating to the provision of the quality reports described in Annexes I and II. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 30 December 2009 and had to become law in the EU countries by 31 December 2016. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Pesticides (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 March 2009 establishing a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides which are plant protection products. For more information, see: Pesticides (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 March 2009 establishing a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides (OJ L 256, 27.10.2009, pp. 86-89) Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 have been incorporated in the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 October 2009 establishing a framework for the Community action to achieve the sustainable use of pesticides (OJ L 256, 27.10.2009, pp. 86-89) See consolidated version. Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 March 2009 establishing a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides (OJ L 256, 27.10.2009, pp. 86-89) See consolidated version. Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 March 2009 establishing a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides (OJ L 256, 27.10.2009, pp. 86-89) See consolidated version. Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 October 2009 establishing a framework for the Community action to achieve the sustainable use of pesticides (OJ L 256, 27.10.2009, pp. 86-89) See consolidated version. Regulation (EC) No 1367/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 September 2006 on the application of the provisions of the Aarhus Convention on Access to Information, Public Participation in Decision-making and Access to Justice in Environmental Matters to Community institutions and bodies (OJ L 120, 30.6.2006, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. last update 27.11.2021



Summary 89:
Plant protection products Plant protection products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 882/2004 on official controls performed to ensure the verification of compliance with feed and food law, animal health and animal welfare rules WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure a high level of protection of plant and animal health and the environment. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to substances, including micro-organisms having general or specific action against harmful organisms or on plants, parts of plants or plant products, referred to as ‘active substances’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing These products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. The regulation applies to products, in the form in which they are supplied to the user, consisting of or containing active substances, safeners or synergists, and intended for one of the following uses: protecting plants or plant products against all harmful organisms or preventing the action of such organisms, unless the main purpose of these products is considered to be for reasons of hygiene rather than for the protection of plants or plant products; influencing the life processes of plants, such as substances influencing these products are referred to as ‘plant protection products’. Internal Internal Information System Internal Market Information System Internal Market Information System Internal Market Information System SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 on the use of an Internal Market Information System for administrative cooperation WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules for the use of an Internal Market Information System (IMI) for administrative cooperation between competent authorities of the Member States and between competent authorities of the Member States and the Commission necessary for the implementation of Union acts in the field of the internal market, within the meaning of Article 26(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), which provide for administrative cooperation, including the exchange of personal data, between Member States or between Member States and the Commission. KEY POINTS The Internal Market Information System (IMI) is a software application accessible via the internet, developed by the European Commission in cooperation with the Member States, in order to assist Member States with the practical implementation of information exchange requirements laid down in Union acts by providing a centralised communication mechanism to facilitate cross-border exchange of information and mutual assistance. In particular, IMI helps competent authorities to identify their counterpart in another Member State, to manage the exchange of information, including personal data, on the basis of simple and unified procedures and to overcome language barriers on the basis of pre-defined and pre-translated workflows. IMI is used for administrative cooperation between competent authorities of the Member States and between competent authorities of the Member States and the Commission necessary for the implementation of Union acts in the field of the internal market, within the meaning of Article 26(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), which provide for administrative cooperation, including the exchange of personal data, between Member States or between Member States and the Commission. EU countries may use IMI for the purpose of administrative cooperation between competent authorities within their territory, in accordance with national law, only where the following conditions are satisfied: no substantial changes to the existing administrative cooperation procedures are required; Uniform Uniform patent protection Unitary patent protection Unitary patent protection Unitary patent protection SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1260/2012 on enhanced cooperation in the area of the creation of unitary patent protection WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a special agreement within the meaning of Article 142 of the Convention on the Grant of European Patents of 5 October 1973, as revised on 17 December 1991 and on 29 November 2000 (the ‘EPC’). Unitary patent protection confers on its proprietor the right to prevent any third party from committing acts against which that patent provides protection throughout the territories of the participating EU countries in which it has unitary effect. It may only be limited, transferred or revoked, or lapse, in respect of all the participating EU countries. It may only be licensed in respect of the whole or part of the territories of the participating EU countries. A European patent granted with the same set of claims in respect of all the participating EU countries shall benefit from unitary effect in the participating EU countries provided that its unitary effect has been registered in the Register for unitary patent protection. A European patent granted with the same set of claims in respect of all the participating EU countries shall benefit from unitary effect in the participating EU countries provided that its unitary effect has been registered in the Register for unitary patent protection. A European patent granted with different sets of claims for different participating EU countries shall not benefit from unitary effect. A European patent granted with the same set of claims in respect of all the participating EU countries shall benefit from unitary effect in the participating EU countries provided that its unitary effect has been registered in the Register for unitary patent protection. Summary 93:
European European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 on the European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights (the Observatory), which is responsible for organising, administering and supporting the activities of national authorities, the private sector and the EU institutions in the fight against infringements of the intellectual property rights covered by Directive 2004/48/EC. KEY POINTS Scope The Observatory is responsible for organising, administering and supporting the gathering of experts, authorities and stakeholders assembled under the name ‘European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights’. The Observatory has the following tasks: improving understanding of the value of intellectual property; improving understanding of the scope and impact of infringements of intellectual property rights; enhancing knowledge of best public and private sector practices to protect intellectual property rights; assisting in raising citizens’ awareness of the impact of infringements of in consultation with the EU countries, programmes for the provision of technical assistance to third countries as well as developing and delivering specific training programmes and events for officials from third countries who are involved in the protection of intellectual property rights; making recommendations to the Commission on issues falling within the scope of the regulation, on the basis of a request from the Commission; carrying out similar activities necessary in order to enable the Observatory to fulfil the tasks set out in the regulation. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 6 June 2012. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 March 2012 on the European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights (OJ L 195, 2.6.2004, pp. 16-19) Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. It aims to ensure the effective exercise of the EU’s rights under international trade agreements, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and by other international trade agreements, including regional or bilateral agreements. KEY POINTS Regulation (EU) No 654/2014 lays down EU rules on the exercise of the EU’s rights for the application and enforcement of international trade rules and amending Council Regulation (EC) No 3286/94. The regulation applies to the following areas: public procurement; intellectual property rights and additional measures concerning services; the origin of a good; the imposition of a mandatory price penalty on tenders of suppliers of goods or services established in and operating from the non-EU country concerned and/or on that part of the tender consisting of goods or services originating in the non-EU country concerned. Stabil Stabil Stabil Stabilisation mechanism for bananas Stabilisation mechanism for bananas SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 20/2013 on the implementation of the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the most appropriate procedures to guarantee the effective application of certain provisions of the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas that have been agreed with Central America. KEY POINTS Safeguard measures The bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas that have been agreed with Central America are designed to prevent serious harm to the EU banana growing sector, particularly in the outermost regions of the EU. The stabilisation mechanism applies to bananas originating in Central America falling under heading 0803 00 19 of the Combined Nomenclature (fresh Bananas, excluding plantains) and listed under category ‘ST’ in the Tariff Elimination Schedule. The stabilisation mechanism applies until 31 December 2019. The stabilisation mechanism applies to bananas originating in Central America falling under heading 0803 00 19 of the Combined Nomenclature (fresh Bananas, excluding plantains) and listed under category ‘ST’ in the Tariff Elimination Schedule. European European Account Preservation Order European Account Preservation Order SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1215/2012 — procedure for obtaining a European Account Preservation Order WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out a procedure allowing a creditor to obtain a European Account Preservation Order (Preservation Order) which prevents the subsequent enforcement of the creditor’s claim from being jeopardised through the transfer or withdrawal of funds up to the amount specified in the order which are held by the debtor or on his behalf in a bank account maintained in an EU country. It does not apply to: rights in property arising out of a matrimonial relationship or out of a relationship deemed by the law applicable to such relationship to have comparable effects to marriage; wills and succession, including maintenance obligations arising by reason of death; wills and succession, including maintenance obligations arising by reason of death; out of a matrimonial relationship or out of a relationship deemed by the law applicable to such relationship to have comparable effects to marriage; wills and succession, including maintenance obligations arising by reason of death; claims against a debtor in relation to whom bankruptcy proceedings, proceedings for the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions, or analogous proceedings have been opened; social security; arbitration. European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1052/2013 on the rules governing the surveillance of the sea external borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules for the surveillance of the sea external borders of the Member States of the European Union (EU) in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Eurosur). KEY POINTS The European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Eurosur) is responsible for the coordination of operational cooperation between Member States in the field of management of the external borders, including as regards border surveillance. It is also responsible for assisting Member States in circumstances requiring increased technical assistance at the external borders, taking into account the fact that some situations may involve humanitarian emergencies and rescue at sea. The European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Eurosur) is responsible for the coordination of operational cooperation between Member States in the field of management of the external borders, including as regards border surveillance. Fund support for police cooperation, preventing and combating crime, and crisis management Internal Security Fund support for police cooperation, preventing and combating crime, and crisis management SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 515/2014 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the EU and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Instrument for Financial Support for Police Cooperation, Prevent and Combating Crime, and Crisis Management (the Instrument), as part of the Internal Security Fund (the Fund). KEY POINTS The Instrument provides financial support for police cooperation, preventing and combating crime, and crisis management (the Instrument), as part of the Internal Security Fund (the Fund). The objectives of the Instrument are to: prevent and combat all types of crime and fighting cross-border, serious and organised crime, in particular projects implementing relevant policy cycles, drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, sexual exploitation of children and projects identifying and dismantling criminal networks, enhancing capacities to fight corruption, protecting the economy against criminal infiltration and reducing financial incentives by seizing, freezing and confiscating criminal assets; prevent and combat cybercrime and raising the levels of security for citizens and business in cyberspace, in particular projects building capacities in law enforcement and the judiciary, projects ensuring work with industry to empower and protect citizens, and projects improving capabilities for dealing with cyber attacks; measures preventing and combating terrorism and addressing radicalisation and recruitment, in particular projects empowering communities to develop local approaches and prevention policies, projects enabling competent authorities to cut off terrorists from access to funding and materials and follow their transactions, projects protecting the transport of passengers and cargo, and projects enhancing the security of explosives and chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear materials. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2014. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Internal Security Strategy (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 515/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 April 2014 establishing as part of the Internal Security Fund, the instrument for financial support for external borders and visa and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (OJ L 298, 26.10.2012, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 515/2014 have been incorporated into the original document. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. It sets out the rules for the application of the European Union’s generalised system of preferences for sustainable development and good governance (GSP) for the period 2006 to 2015. It provides for the following tariff preferences under the scheme: a general arrangement; a special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+); and a special arrangement for the least-developed countries (Everything But Arms). KEY POINTS The regulation provides for the following tariff preferences under the scheme: a general arrangement; a special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+); and a special arrangement for the least-developed countries (Everything But Arms). The special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance is granted if the following conditions are met: a GSP beneficiary country has made a request to that effect; and examination of the request shows that the requesting country fulfils the conditions laid down in Article 9(1). Special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance is granted if the following conditions are met: a GSP beneficiary country has made a request to that effect; and examination of the request shows that the requesting country fulfils the conditions laid down in Article 9(1). The special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance is suspended temporarily, in respect of all or of certain products originating in a GSP+ beneficiary country, where in practice that country does not respect its binding undertakings as referred to in points (d), (e) and (f) of Article 9(1); or the GSP+ beneficiary country has formulated a reservation which is prohibited by any of the relevant conventions or which is incompatible with the object and purpose of that convention as established in point (c) of Article 9(1); Firearms of firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition UN Firearms of firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 652/2012 — rules governing export authorisation, and import and transit measures for firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules governing export authorisation, and import and transit measures for firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition, for the purpose of implementing Article 10 of the United Nations Protocol against the Illicit Manufacturing of and Trafficking in Firearms, their Parts and Components and Ammunition, supplementing the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organised Crime (the ‘UN Firearms Protocol’). KEY POINTS An export authorisation is required for the export of firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition. This authorisation must be issued by the competent authorities of the EU country where the exporter is established and issued in writing or by electronic means. This authorisation must be granted by the competent authorities of the EU country where the exporter is established and issued in writing or by electronic means. If the firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition are located in one or more EU countries other than the one where the application for export authorisation has been made, that fact shall be indicated on that application. Before issuing an export authorisation for firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition, the EU country concerned must verify that: the importing third country has authorised the relevant import; and the third countries of transit, if any, have given notice in writing and at the latest prior to shipment. If no objection to the transit is received within 20 working days from the day of the written request for no objection to the transit submitted by the exporter, the consulted third country of transit shall be regarded as having no objection to the transit. If no objection to the transit is received within 20 working days from the day of the written request for no objection to the transit, the consulted third country of transit shall be regarded as having no objection to the transit. If no objection to the transit is received within 20 working days from the day of the written request for no objection to the transit, the consulted third country of transit shall be regarded as having no objection to the transit. If no objection to the transit, the consulted third country of transit shall be regarded as having no objection to the transit. If no objection to the transit is received within 20 working days from the day of the written request for no objection to the transit, the consulted third country of transit shall be regarded as having no objection to the transit. If no objection to the transit, the consulted third country of transit shall be regarded as having no objection to the transit. The competent authority of the EU country responsible for issuing the export authorisation must supply the necessary documents proving that the importing third country has authorised the import and that the third country has authorised the import and that the third country of transit had no objection to the transit. The exporter must supply the competent authority of the EU country responsible for issuing the export authorisation with the necessary documents proving that the importing third country has authorised the import and that the third country has authorised the import and that the third country of transit had no objection to the transit. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 19 April 2012. BACKGROUND For more information, see: UN Firearms Protocol (European Commission). MAIN 652/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 October 2011 on rules governing export authorisation, import and transit measures for firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition (OJ L 179, 8.7.2008, pp.

European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR) European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1052/2013 — establishing a European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up a European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR) to detect, prevent and combat illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contribute to the protection and saving of the lives of migrants. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to the surveillance of external land and sea borders, including the monitoring, detection, identification, tracking, prevention and interception of unauthorised border crossings for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. The regulation does not apply to any legal or administrative measure taken once the responsible authorities of a Member State have intercepted cross-border criminal activities or unauthorised crossings by persons of the external borders. The regulation does not apply to any legal or administrative measure taken once the responsible authorities of a Member State have intercepted cross-border criminal activities or unauthorised crossings by persons of the external borders. The regulation does not apply to any legal or administrative measure taken once the responsible authorities of a Member State have intercepted cross-border criminal activities or unauthorised crossings by persons of the external borders. The regulation does not apply to any legal or administrative measure taken once the responsible authorities of a Member State have intercepted cross-border criminal activities or unauthorised crossings by persons of the external borders. The regulation does not affect the division of competence between the Union and the Member States or the obligations of Member States under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, the International Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue, the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and its Protocol against the Smuggling of Migrants by Land, Sea and Air, the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms and other relevant international instruments. The regulation does not affect the division of competence between the Union and the Member States or the obligations of Member States under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, the International Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue, the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and its Protocol against the Smuggling of Migrants by Land, Sea and Air, the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms and other relevant international instruments. The regulation does not affect the division of competence between the Union and the Member States or the obligations of Member States under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, the International Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue, the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and its Protocol against the Smuggling of Migrants by Land, Sea and Air, the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms and other relevant international instruments. The regulation does not affect Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council or the rules for the surveillance of sea external borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the Agency. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 2 December 2013. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Border Surveillance System (European Commission). Euro system for preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences Euro system for preventing, detecting and investigating terrorist offences and other serious criminal offences SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 604/2013 on access for consultation of Eurodac by designated authorities of Member States and by Europol for the purposes of the prevention, detection or investigation of terrorist offences or of other serious criminal offences WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the conditions for access for consultation of Eurodac* by designated authorities of Member States and by Europol for the purposes of the prevention, detection or investigation of terrorist offences or of other serious criminal offences. KEY POINTS Eurodac consists of: a computerised central fingerprint database composed of: a Central Unit, a Business Continuity Plan and System; a communication infrastructure between the Central System and Member States that provides an encrypted virtual network dedicated to Eurodac data; each Member State has a single National Access Point. Each Member State must promptly take the fingerprints of all fingers of every applicant for international protection of at least 14 years of age and shall, as soon as possible and no later than 72 hours after the lodging of his or her application for international protection, transmit them to the Central System the following data in relation to any third-country national or stateless person, who is not turned back: fingerprint data; Member State of origin, place and date of the apprehension; sex; reference number used by the Member State of origin; date on which the fingerprints were taken; date on which the data were transmitted to the Central System; operator user ID. Each Member State must promptly take the fingerprints of all fingers of every applicant for international protection of at least 14 years of age and shall, as soon as possible and no later than 72 hours after the lodging of his or her application for international protection, transmit them to the Central System the following data in relation to any third-country national or stateless person, who is not turned back: fingerprint data; Member State of origin, place and date of the apprehension; sex; reference number used by the Member State of origin; date on which the fingerprints were taken; date on which the data were transmitted to the Central System; operator user ID. Each Member State must promptly take the fingerprints of all fingers of every applicant for international protection of at least 14 years of age and shall, as soon as possible and no later than 72 hours after the lodging of his or her application for international protection, transmit them to the Central System the following data in relation to any third-country national or stateless person, who is not turned back: fingerprint data; Member State of origin, place and date of the apprehension; sex; reference number used by the Member State of origin; date on which the fingerprints were taken; date on which the data were transmitted to the Central System; operator user ID. Each Member State must promptly take the fingerprints of all fingers of every applicant for international protection of at least 14 years of age and shall, as soon as possible and no later than 72 hours after the lodging of his or her application for international protection, transmit them to the Central System. Protecting protection of designations of origin and geographical indications for agricultural products and foodstuffs Protecting protection of designations of origin and geographical indications for agricultural products and foodstuffs SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 509/2012 on the protection of designations of origin and geographical indications for agricultural products and foodstuffs WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules for the protection of designations of origin and geographical indications for agricultural products and foodstuffs. The regulation covers agricultural products intended for human consumption listed in Annex I to the Treaty and other agricultural products and foodstuffs listed in Annex I to this regulation. These products are closely linked to agricultural products or to the rural economy. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation covers agricultural products intended for human consumption listed in Annex I to the Treaty and other agricultural products and foodstuffs listed in Annex I to this regulation. Summary 110:
Mobility Mobility Mobility of labour within the EU Freedom of movement of labour within the EU SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1151/2011 on freedom of movement for workers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that workers in the EU can move freely within the EU in order to pursue activities as employed persons subject to any limitations justified on grounds of public policy, public security or public health. It aims to ensure that workers in the EU can move freely within the EU in order to pursue activities as employed persons subject to any limitations justified on grounds of public policy, public security or public health. KEY POINTS Any national of an EU country must, irrespective of his place of residence, have the right to take up an activity as an employed person and to pursue such activity, within the territory of another EU country in accordance with the provisions laid down by law, regulation or administrative action governing the employment of nationals of that country. He must, in particular, have the right to take up available employment in the territory of another EU country with the same priority as nationals of that country. Any national of an EU country and any employer pursuing an activity in the territory of an EU country may exchange their applications for and offers of employment, and may conclude and perform contracts of employment in accordance with the provisions in force laid down by law, regulation or administrative action, without any discrimination resulting therefrom. The engagement and recruitment of a national of one EU country for a post in another EU country shall not depend on medical, vocational or other criteria which are discriminatory on grounds of nationality by comparison with those applied to nationals of the other EU country who wish to pursue the same activity. The engagement and recruitment of a national of one EU country for a post in another EU country shall not depend on medical, vocational or other criteria which are discriminatory on grounds of nationality by comparison with those applied to nationals of the other EU country who wish to pursue the same activity. Ozone ozone ozone layer ozone layer ozone layer SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 2037/2000 on the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules on the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer. KEY POINTS The regulation covers the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer, on the reporting of information related to those substances and on the import, export, placing on the market and use of products and equipment containing or relying on those substances. Regulation (EC) No 2037/2000 repeals Regulation (EC) No 2037/2000 as from 1 January 2010. KEY POINTS The regulation covers the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer, on the reporting of information related to those substances and on the import, export, placing on the market and use of products and equipment containing or relying on those substances. The regulation does not apply to new substances if they are used as feedstock or for laboratory and analytical uses, to imports for transit through the customs territory of the EU or imports under the temporary storage, customs warehousing or free zone procedure. The regulation does not apply to new substances if they are used as process agents, to imports for transit through the customs territory of the EU or imports under the temporary storage, customs warehousing or free zone procedure. Summary 112:
European information and observation network European information and observation network SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1210/90 on the setting up of a European Environment Information and Observation Network WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up a European Environment Information and Observation Network (EEAN) to provide objective, reliable and comparable information on the state of the EU’s environment. KEY POINTS The EEAN is responsible for collecting, analysing and disseminating information on the EU’s environment. The main areas of activity of the EEAN are: air quality and atmospheric emissions; water quality, pollutants and water resources; the state of the soil, of the fauna and flora, and of biotopes; land use and natural resources; waste management; noise emissions; chemical substances which are hazardous for the environment; coastal and marine protection. EU countries may cooperate with the EEAN and contribute to the work of the European Environment Information and Observation Network in accordance with the work programme of the Agency by collecting, collating and analysing data nationwide. EU countries may also join to cooperate in these activities at a transnational level. The EEAN comprises: the main component elements of the national information networks;the national focal points for coordinating and/or transmitting the information to be supplied at national level to the EEAN and to the EEAN institutions or bodies forming part of the EEAN;the topic centres for coordinating and/or transmitting the information to be supplied at national level to the EEAN and to the Eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS) Eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1221/2009 on the voluntary participation by organisations in a Community eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a Community eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS) to encourage organisations to publish rigorous and independently verified environmental or sustainable development performance reports. It aims to improve the environmental performance of companies in the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules for the registration, renewal, suspension and deletion of organisations from the EU’s eco-management and audit system (EMAS) register. The EMAS logo must be used only by registered organisations and only as long as their registration is valid. The EMAS logo must not be used: on products or their packaging; in conjunction with comparative claims concerning other activities and services or in a way that may create confusion with environmental product labels. The EMAS logo must not be used: on products or their packaging; in conjunction with comparative claims concerning other activities and services or in a way that may create confusion with environmental product labels. Summary 115:
Common rules for safeguarding civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference Protecting civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 2320/2002 establishing common rules in the field of civil aviation security WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes common rules to protect civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference that jeopardise the security of civil aviation. It also provides a basis for a common interpretation of Annex 17 to the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all airports or parts of airports located in the territory of an EU country that are not exclusively used for military purposes. The regulation applies to the following: all airports or parts of airports located in the territory of an EU country that are not exclusively used for military purposes; all operators, including air carriers, providing services at airports referred to in point (a); all entities applying aviation security standards that operate from premises located inside or outside airport premises and provide goods and/or services to or through airports referred to in point (a). The regulation applies to the following: all airports or parts of airports located in the territory of a EU country that are not exclusively used for military purposes; all operators, including air carriers, providing services at airports referred to in point (a); all entities applying aviation security standards that operate from premises located inside or outside airport premises and provide goods and/or services to or through airports referred to in point (a). The regulation applies to the following: all airports or parts of airports located in the territory of a EU country that are not exclusively used for military purposes; all operators, including air carriers, providing services at airports referred to in point (a); all entities applying aviation security standards that operate from premises located inside or outside airport premises and provide goods and/or services to or through airports referred to in point (a). The regulation applies to the following: all airports or parts of airports located in the territory of a EU country that are not exclusively used for military purposes; all operators, including air carriers, providing services at airports referred to in point (a); all entities applying aviation security standards that operate from premises located inside or outside airport premises and provide goods and/or services to or through airports referred to in point (a); the regulation applies to the following: all airports or parts of airports located in the territory of a Member State that are not exclusively used for military purposes; all operators, including air carriers, providing services at airports referred to in point (a); Sancting of funds and economic resources Targeted restrictive measures SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 on the freezing of funds and economic resources of, and the prohibition to make funds and economic resources available to, natural or legal persons, entities or bodies responsible for, providing support to or otherwise involved in serious human rights violations or abuses, as well as those associated with the natural and legal persons, entities and bodies. Summary 117:
EU EU EU military operation in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED IRINI) EU military operation in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED IRINI) SUMMARY OF: Council Decision (CFSP) 2020/472 on a European Union military operation in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED IRINI) Decision (CFSP) 2019/1595 amending Decision (CFSP) 2015/778 on a European Union military operation in the Southern Central Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED operation SOPHIA) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It authorises the European Union (EU) military operation in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED IRINI) to contribute to the implementation of the UN arms embargo on Libya by using aerial, satellite and maritime assets. KEY POINTS EUNAVFOR MED IRINI aims to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya, including crude oil and refined petroleum products. It also contributes to the implementation of UN measures to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya in accordance with UNSCR 2146 (2014) and subsequent resolutions, in particular UNSCR 2509 (2020) and UNSCR 2510 (2020). It also contributes to the disruption of the business model of human smuggling and trafficking networks, in accordance with applicable international law, including the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, any relevant UNSCR, and international human rights law as applicable. EUNAVFOR MED IRINI, as its core task, contributes to the implementation of the UN arms embargo on Libya with aerial, satellite and maritime assets. It also collects extensive and comprehensive information on the trafficking of arms and related materiel from all directions and shares it with relevant partners and agencies on a case-by-case and need-to-know basis through the mechanisms in the relevant planning documents in order to contribute to a full situational awareness in the area of operation and in the area of interest. Classified information EUNAVFOR MED IRINI, as its core task, collects extensive and comprehensive information on the trafficking of arms and related materiel from all directions and shares it with relevant partners and agencies on a case-by-case and need-to-know basis through the mechanisms in the relevant planning documents in order to contribute to a full situational awareness in the area of operation and in the area of interest. It also contributes to the disruption of the business model of human smuggling and trafficking networks, in accordance with applicable international law, including the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, any relevant UNSCR, and international human rights law as applicable. MAIN DOCUMENT Council Decision (CFSP) 2020/472 of 31 March 2020 on a European Union military operation in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED IRINI) (OJ L 10, 1.4.2020, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Council Decision (CFSP) 2020/472 have been incorporated in the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Common fisheries policy Common fisheries policy SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 establishing a multiannual plan for fisheries exploiting stocks of plaice and sole in the North Sea WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a multiannual plan for fisheries exploiting stocks of plaice and sole in the North Sea. It aims to: contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the common fisheries policy listed in Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013, in particular by applying the precautionary approach to fisheries management; ensure that exploitation of living marine biological resources restores and maintains populations of harvested species above levels which can produce MSY; contribute to the elimination of discards, by avoiding and reducing, as far as possible, unwanted catches, and to the implementation of the landing obligation in Union waters of the North Sea for all stocks of species to which the landing obligation applies under Article 15 of Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 for the species which are subject to catch limits and to which this regulation applies. WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? South South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (SPRFMO) South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (SPRFMO) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/2403 laying down rules for issuing and managing fishing authorisations for Union fishing vessels conducting fishing operations in waters under the auspices of a regional fisheries management organisation WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? Regulation (EU) 2017/2403 lays down rules for issuing and managing fishing authorisations for Union fishing vessels conducting fishing operations in waters under the auspices of a regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) to which the Union is a contracting party. It aims to ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable use of fishery resources through the application of the precautionary approach to fisheries management and an ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management, and, in so doing, to safeguard the marine ecosystems in which those resources occur. KEY POINTS Regulation (EU) 2017/2403 lays down rules for issuing and managing fishing authorisations for Union fishing vessels conducting fishing operations in waters under the auspices of a regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) to which the Union is a contracting party. Prevent controls on cash entering or leaving the European Union (EU) controls on cash entering or leaving the European Union (EU) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/1939 on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to prevent and detect money laundering and terrorist financing by laying down a system of controls applicable to natural persons who enter or leave the EU carrying amounts of cash or bearer-negotiable instruments equal to or greater than  10 000 or its equivalent in other currencies. KEY POINTS The regulation lays down a system of controls applicable to natural persons who enter or leave the EU carrying amounts of cash or bearer-negotiable instruments equal to or greater than  10 000 or its equivalent in other currencies. The regulation does not concern measures taken by the EU or Member States under Article 66 TFEU to restrict movements of capital that cause, or threaten to cause, serious difficulties for the operation of economic and monetary union or under Articles 143 and 144 TFEU as a result of a sudden crisis in the balance of payments. The regulation does not concern measures taken by the EU or Member States under Article 66 TFEU to restrict movements of capital that cause, or threaten to cause, serious difficulties for the operation of economic and monetary union or under Articles 143 and 144 TFEU as a result of a sudden crisis in the balance of payments. Energy Union (EU) Energy Union (EU) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/842 on binding annual greenhouse gas emission reductions by EU countries from 2021 to 2030 contributing to climate action to meet commitments under the Paris Agreement and amending Regulation (EU) No 525/2013 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure the achievement of the Energy Union’s five dimensions: energy security; the internal energy market; energy efficiency; decarbonisation; and research, innovation and competitiveness. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the five dimensions of the Energy Union: energy security; the internal energy market; energy efficiency; decarbonisation; and research, innovation and competitiveness. EU countries are encouraged to provide their first draft integrated national energy and climate plans as early as possible in 2018, in order to allow proper preparation, in particular for the facilitative dialogue to be convened in 2018 in accordance with Decision 1/CP.21 of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). EU countries are encouraged to provide their first draft integrated national energy and climate plans as early as possible in 2018, in order to allow proper preparation, in particular for the facilitative dialogue to be convened in 2018 in accordance with Decision 1/CP.21 of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Persistent persistent organic pollutants (POPs) Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/005 on persistent organic pollutants WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the management of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) in the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation prohibits the manufacture, placing on the market and use of substances listed in Annex I of the regulation, whether on their own, in mixtures or in articles. The regulation does not apply to: a substance used for laboratory-scale research or as a reference standard; a substance present as an unintentional trace contaminant, as specified in the relevant entries of Annex I or II, in substances, mixtures or articles. Reducing plastic products and fishing gear in the EU Reducing plastic products and fishing gear in the EU SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/883 on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States concerning the manufacture, presentation and sale of tobacco and related products and repealing Directive 2001/37/EC WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to prevent and reduce the negative environmental, health and economic impact of single-use plastic products and fishing gear in the EU. KEY POINTS Single-use plastic products include a diverse range of commonly used fast-moving consumer products that are discarded after having been used once for the purpose for which they were provided, are rarely recycled, and are prone to becoming litter. Single-use plastic products include a diverse range of commonly used fast-moving consumer products that are discarded after having been used once for the purpose for which they were provided, are rarely recycled, and are prone to becoming litter. These products include fast-food containers or meal, sandwich, wrap and salad boxes with cold or hot food, food containers of fresh or processed food that does not need further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Examples of food containers that are not to be considered as single-use plastic products for the purposes of this directive are food containers with dried food or food that is sold cold requiring further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Single-use plastic products covered by the directive are: fast-food containers or meal, sandwich, wrap and salad boxes with cold or hot food, food containers of fresh or processed food that does not need further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Examples of food containers that are not to be considered as single-use plastic products for the purposes of this directive are: fast-food containers or meal, sandwich, wrap and salad boxes with cold or hot food, food containers of fresh or processed food that does not need further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Single-use plastic products covered by the directive are: food containers with dried food or food that is sold cold requiring further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Examples of food containers that are not to be considered as single-use plastic products for the purposes of this directive are: fast-food containers or meal, sandwich, wrap and salad boxes with cold or hot food, food containers of fresh or processed food that does not need further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Single-use plastic products covered by the directive are: food containers with dried food or food that is sold cold requiring further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Single-use plastic products covered by the directive are: food containers with dried food or food that is sold cold requiring further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Single-use plastic products covered by the directive are: food containers with dried food or food that is sold cold requiring further preparation, containers containing food in more than single-serve portions or single-serve portion-sized food containers sold in more than one unit. Single-use plastic products covered by the directive are: fast-food containers or meal, sandwich, wrap and salad boxes with cold or hot food, or food containers of fresh or processed food that does not need further preparation, such as fruits, vegetables or desserts. Single-use plastic products covered by the directive are: beverage bottles or composite beverage packaging used for beer, wine, water, liquid refreshments, juices and nectars, instant beverages or milk, but not cups for beverages as these are a separate category of single-use plastic products for the purposes of this directive. By 3 July 2021, the European Commission will adopt an implementing act laying down the methodology for the calculation and verification of the ambitious and sustained reduction in the consumption of the single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex. By 3 July 2020, the Commission will adopt an implementing act laying down the methodology for the calculation and verification of the ambitious and sustained reduction in the consumption of the single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex. By 3 July 2021, the Commission will adopt an implementing act laying down the methodology for the calculation and verification of the separate collection targets for recycling: by 2025, of an amount of waste single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex equal to 77 % of such single-use plastic products placed on the market in a given year by weight; by 2029, of an amount of waste single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex to this directive equal to 90 % of such single-use plastic products placed on the market in a given year by weight; by 2029, of an amount of waste single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex to this directive equal to 77 % of such single-use plastic products placed on the market in a given year by weight. By 3 July 2021, the Commission will adopt an implementing act laying down the methodology for the calculation and verification of the ambitious and sustained reduction in the consumption of the single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex to the directive on the territory of the Member State by 2026 compared to 2022. By 3 July 2021, the Commission will adopt an implementing act laying down the methodology for the calculation and verification of the ambitious and sustained reduction in the consumption of the single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex to the directive on the territory of the Member State by 2026 compared to 2022. By 3 July 2021, the Commission will adopt an implementing act laying down the methodology for the calculation and verification of the ambitious and sustained reduction in the consumption of the single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex to 90 % of such single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the directive on the territory of the Member State by 2026 compared to 2022. By 3 July 2021, the Commission will adopt an implementing act laying down the methodology for the calculation and verification of the ambitious and sustained reduction in the consumption of the single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the Annex to 90 % of such single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the directive on the territory of the Member State by 2026 compared to 2022.
