Access access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled Access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/1564 on certain permitted uses of certain works and other subject matter protected by copyright and related rights for the benefit of persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the availability of accessible format copies for beneficiaries persons in all of the EU and the circulation of such copies within the internal market, and requires Member States to introduce a mandatory exception to certain rights that are harmonised by EU law. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to the export and import arrangements for accessible format copies for non-commercial purposes for the benefit of beneficiaries persons between the EU and non-EU countries that are parties to the Marrakesh Treaty, and to lay down the conditions for such export and import in a uniform manner within the field harmonised by Directives 2001/29/EC and (EU) 2017/1564 in order to ensure that those measures are applied consistently throughout the internal market and do not jeopardise the harmonisation of exclusive rights and exceptions contained within those directives. It also allows for the importation of, and access to, accessible format copies made in accordance with the implementation of the Marrakesh Treaty, from a third country, by beneficiary persons in the EU and authorised entities established in a Member State, for non-commercial purposes for the benefit of persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled. It also allows for the importation of, and access to, accessible format copies made in accordance with the implementation of the Marrakesh Treaty, from a third country, by beneficiary persons in the EU and authorised entities established in a Member State, for non-commercial purposes for the benefit of persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled. It also allows for the importation of, and access to, accessible format copies made in accordance with the implementation of the Marrakesh Treaty, from a third country, by beneficiary persons in the EU and authorised entities established in a Member State, for non-commercial purposes for the benefit of persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled. Summary 129:
Medical medical devices in vitro Diagnostic medical devices in vitro SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/745 — rules for the placing on the market and putting into service of in vitro diagnostic medical devices WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the placing on the market and putting into service of in vitro diagnostic medical devices and their accessories on the EU market. It aims to ensure the smooth functioning of the internal market as regards in vitro diagnostic medical devices, taking as a base a high level of protection of health for patients and users, and taking into account the small and medium-sized enterprises that are active in this sector. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules for the placing on the market and putting into service of in vitro diagnostic medical devices and their accessories on the EU market. The regulation applies to all devices placed on the market except devices for performance studies, and is based on internationally recognised principles including definitions that are compatible with those used by major trade partners. Manufacturers must keep the technical documentation, the EU declaration of conformity and, if applicable, a copy of the relevant certificate, including any amendments and supplements, issued in accordance with Article 51, available for the competent authorities for a period of at least 10 years after the last device covered by the EU declaration of conformity has been placed on the market. Manufacturers must carry out a performance evaluation in accordance with the requirements set out in Article 56 and Annex XIII, including a PMPF. Manufacturers must keep the technical documentation, the EU declaration of conformity and, if applicable, a copy of the relevant certificate, including any amendments and supplements, issued in accordance with Article 51, available for the competent authorities for a period of at least 10 years after the last device covered by the EU declaration of conformity has been placed on the market. Where the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately take the necessary corrective action to bring that device into conformity to withdraw it or to recall it, as appropriate. If the device presents a serious risk, manufacturers must immediately inform the competent authorities of the EU countries in which they made the device available and, where applicable, the notified body that issued a certificate for the device in accordance with Article 51, in particular, of the non-compliance and of any corrective action taken. Food and nutrition information Food and nutrition information SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 882/2004 on food information WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for food labelling, in particular the country of origin or place of origin of a food. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to catering services provided by transport companies when the departure takes place on the territories of the EU countries to which the Treaties apply. It covers the following categories: information on the identity and composition, properties or other characteristics of the food; information on the protection of consumers’ health and the safe use of a food; information on nutritional characteristics so as to enable consumers, including those with special dietary requirements, to make informed choices. Scope The regulation covers the following categories: information on the identity and composition, properties or other characteristics of the food; information on the protection of consumers’ health and the safe use of a food; information on nutritional characteristics so as to enable consumers, including those with special dietary requirements, to make informed choices. Where mandatory food information is required by food information law, it must concern information that falls, in particular, into one of the following categories: information on the identity and composition, properties or other characteristics of the food; information on the protection of consumers’ health and the safe use of a food; information on nutritional characteristics so as to enable consumers, including those with special dietary requirements, to make informed choices. Food business operators, within the businesses under their control, must not modify the information accompanying a food if such modification would mislead the final consumer or otherwise reduce the level of consumer protection and the possibilities for the final consumer to make informed choices. In exceptional cases, the name of the food in the EU country of production shall not be used in the EU country of marketing when the food which it designates in the EU country of origin or place of provenance is so different, as regards its composition or manufacture, from the food known under that name in the EU country of marketing that paragraph 2 is not sufficient to ensure, in the EU country of marketing, correct information for consumers. In exceptional cases, the name of the food in the EU country of production shall not be used in the EU country of marketing when the food which it designates in the EU country of origin or place of provenance is so different, as regards its composition or manufacture, from the food known under that name in the EU country of marketing that paragraph 2 is not sufficient to ensure, in the EU country of marketing, correct information for consumers. In exceptional cases, the name of the food in the EU country of origin or place of provenance is not used in the EU country of marketing when the food which it designates in the EU country of origin or place of provenance is so different, as regards its composition or manufacture, from the food known under that name in the EU country of marketing that paragraph 2 is not sufficient to ensure, in the EU country of marketing, correct information for consumers. In exceptional cases, the name of the food in the EU country of origin or place of provenance is not used in the EU country of marketing when the food which it designates in the EU country of origin or place of provenance is so different, as regards its composition or manufacture, from the food known under that name in the EU country of marketing that paragraph 2 is not sufficient to ensure, in the EU country of marketing, correct information for consumers. European of the European Social Fund (ESF) European of the European Social Fund (ESF) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1301/2013 on the European Regional Development Fund and the Investment for growth and jobs goal and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1080/2006 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the missions of the European Social Fund (ESF), including the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI), the scope of its support, specific provisions and the types of expenditure eligible for assistance. It aims to improve employment opportunities, strengthen social inclusion, fight poverty, promote education, skills and life-long learning and develop active, comprehensive and sustainable inclusion policies in accordance with the tasks entrusted to the ESF by Article 162 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), and thereby contribute to economic, social and territorial cohesion in accordance with Article 174 TFEU. KEY POINTS The ESF aims to improve employment opportunities, strengthen social inclusion, fight poverty, promote education, skills and life-long learning and develop active, comprehensive and sustainable inclusion policies in accordance with the tasks entrusted to the ESF by Article 162 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), and thereby contribute to economic, social and territorial cohesion in accordance with Article 174 TFEU. The ESF supports the development and competitiveness of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises of the EU and to ensure that people can adapt, through acquiring appropriate skills and through lifelong learning opportunities, to new challenges such as the shift to a knowledge-based economy, the digital agenda, and the transition to a low-carbon and more energy-efficient economy. The ESF contributes to the Europe 2020 strategy, ensuring a greater concentration of support on the priorities of the EU. A minimum share of cohesion policy funding for the ESF is established in accordance with Article 92(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013. The choice and number of investment priorities for ESF support should also be limited, in accordance with the level of development of the supported regions. The choice and number of investment priorities for ESF support should also be limited, in accordance with the level of development of the supported regions. The choice and number of investment priorities for ESF support should also be limited, in accordance with the level of development of the supported regions. The choice and number of investment priorities for ESF support should also be limited, in accordance with the level of development of the supported regions. The choice and number of investment priorities for ESF support should also be limited, in accordance with the level of development of the supported regions. The choice and number of investment priorities for ESF support should also be limited, in accordance with the level of development of the supported regions. EU EU population and vital events EU population and vital events SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1059/2013 — common legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics on population and vital events WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics on population and vital events. KEY POINTS EU countries must provide the European Commission (Eurostat) with data on their usually resident population at national level, within 8 months of the end of the reference year. EU countries may estimate the total population from the legally resident or registered population using scientifically-based, well-documented, and publicly available statistical estimation methods. EU countries may also estimate the total population from the legally resident or registered population using scientifically-based, well-documented, and publicly available statistical estimation methods. EU countries may also estimate the total population from the legally resident or registered population using scientifically-based, well-documented, and publicly available statistical estimation methods. Label labelling and marking of textile products Labelling and marking of textile products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 765/2008 — rules concerning the use of textile fibre names and related labelling and marking of fibre composition of textile products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules concerning the use of textile fibre names and related labelling and marking of fibre composition of textile products, rules concerning the labelling or marking of textile products containing non-textile parts of animal origin and rules concerning the determination of the fibre composition of textile products by quantitative analysis of binary and ternary textile fibre mixtures, with a view to improving the functioning of the internal market and to providing accurate information to consumers. KEY POINTS The regulation lays down rules concerning the use of textile fibre names and related labelling and marking of fibre composition of textile products, rules concerning the labelling or marking of textile products containing non-textile parts of animal origin and rules concerning the determination of the fibre composition of textile products by quantitative analysis of binary and ternary textile fibre mixtures, with a view to improving the functioning of the internal market and to providing accurate information to consumers. The regulation does not apply to textile products which are contracted out to persons working in their own homes or to independent firms that carry out work from materials supplied without the property therein being transferred for consideration. Summary 138:
Ensur Ensuring the transparency of transferable securities (PRIIPs) Ensuring the transparency of transferable securities (PRIIPs) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010 on the format and content of the key information document for PRIIPs WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules on the format and content of the key information document to be drawn up by PRIIP manufacturers and on the provision of the key information document to retail investors in order to enable them to understand and compare the PRIIP’s key features and risks. KEY INFORMATION DOCUMENT The key information document must contain the following information: the name of the PRIIP, the identity and contact details of the PRIIP manufacturer, information about the competent authority of the PRIIP manufacturer and the date of the key information document. The key information document must contain the following information: at the beginning of the document, the name of the PRIIP, the identity and contact details of the PRIIP manufacturer, information about the competent authority of the PRIIP manufacturer and the date of the key information document; where applicable, a comprehension alert which will read: ‘You are about to purchase a product that is not simple and may be difficult to understand’; under a section titled ‘What are the costs?’, the costs associated with an investment in the PRIIP, comprising both direct and indirect costs to be borne by the retail investor, including one-off and recurring costs, presented by means of summary indicators of these costs and, to ensure comparability, total aggregate costs expressed in monetary and percentage terms, to show the compound effects of the total costs on the investment. The key information document may be provided using a durable medium other than paper if the following conditions are met: the use of the durable medium is appropriate in the context of the business conducted between the person advising on, or selling, the PRIIP and the retail investor; the key information document remains accessible on the website, capable of being downloaded and stored in a durable medium, for such period of time as the retail investor may need to consult it. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 30 December 2014. BACKGROUND For more information, see: PRIIPs (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014 on markets in financial instruments and amending Directive 2002/92/EC and Directive 2011/61/EU (OJ L 173, 12.6.2014, pp. 84-89) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Single Single Single Resolution Mechanism (SSM) Single Resolution Mechanism (SSM) Single Resolution Mechanism (SSM) Single Resolution Mechanism (SSM) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 on the single resolution mechanism for failing banks WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up a single resolution mechanism (SSM) for failing banks in the European Union (EU). The single resolution mechanism (SSM) is one of the EU’s main tools for the resolution of failing banks. It aims to improve the functioning of the EU’s single market for banking services. It also aims to ensure a level playing field between EU countries. KEY POINTS The Single Resolution Mechanism (SSM) is a centralised power of resolution established and entrusted to the Single Resolution Board established in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 and to the national resolution authorities. The single resolution fund is supported by a single resolution fund (‘the Fund’). The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as well as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as well as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as well as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as well as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as well as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as well as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as well as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. The use of the Fund is contingent upon the entry into force of an agreement among the participating EU countries on transferring the funds raised at national level towards the Fund as well as on a progressive merger of the different funds raised at national level to be allocated to national compartments of the Fund. Noise Noise-related operating restrictions at EU airports Noise-related operating restrictions at EU airports SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 652/2014 on noise-related operating restrictions at EU airports WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules on the process to be followed for the introduction of noise-related operating restrictions at EU airports. It aims to: facilitate the achievement of specific noise abatement objectives, including health aspects, at the level of individual airports, while respecting relevant EU rules, in particular those laid down in Directive 2002/49/EC, and the legislation within each EU country; enable the use of operating restrictions in accordance with the Balanced Approach so as to achieve the sustainable development of the airport and air traffic management network capacity from a gate-to-gate perspective. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to aircraft engaged in civil aviation. It does not apply to aircraft engaged in military, customs, police or similar operations. It does not apply to aircraft engaged in military, customs, police or similar operations. Statistics statistics on public health and safety at work EU statistics on public health and safety at work SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 322/97 establishing a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on public health and safety at work WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on public health and safety at work. KEY POINTS EU countries must compile data concerning public health and health and safety at work from sources which, depending on the domains and subjects and on the characteristics of the national systems, consist of either household or similar surveys or survey modules, or national administrative or reporting sources. The statistics provide data for structural indicators, sustainable development indicators and European Community Health Indicators (ECHI), as well as for the other sets of indicators which it is necessary to develop for the purpose of monitoring EU actions in the fields of public health and health and safety at work. The statistics must include, in the form of a harmonised and common data set, information required for EU action in the field of public health, for supporting national strategies for the development of high-quality, universally accessible and sustainable health care as well as for Community action in the field of health and safety at work. The statistics must include, in the form of a harmonised and common data set, information required for EU action in the field of public health, for supporting national strategies for the development of high-quality, universally accessible and sustainable health care as well as for Community action in the field of health and safety at work. The methods used for the implementation of the data collections must take into consideration, including in the case of preparatory activities, national experience and expertise, and national specificities, capacities and existing data collections, in the framework of the collaborative networks and other European Statistical System (ESS) structures with Member States set up by the Commission (Eurostat). The methodologies for regular data collections which result from projects with a statistical dimension carried out under other Community programmes such as the public health or the research programmes shall also be taken into consideration. The methodologies for regular data collections which result from projects with a statistical dimension carried out under other Community programmes such as the public health or the research programmes shall also be taken into consideration. Employment Employment Statistics (EURES) Employment Statistics (EURES) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1882/2003 on Community job vacancy statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the requirements for the regular quarterly production of EU job vacancy statistics. KEY POINTS EU countries must submit to the European Commission (Eurostat) data on job vacancies at least for business units with one employee or more. The data cover all economic activities defined by the common classification system for economic activities in the Community (NACE) in force, except for the activities of households as employers and the activities of extraterritorial organisations and bodies. EU countries must also provide data on occupied posts in order to standardise job vacancy data for comparative purposes. EU countries must apply seasonal adjustment procedures to the quarterly job vacancy data. EU countries must also provide data on occupied posts in order to standardise job vacancy data for comparative purposes. EU countries must also provide data on occupied posts in order to standardise job vacancy data for comparative purposes. EU countries must also provide data on occupied posts in order to standardise job vacancy data for comparative purposes. EU countries must also provide data on occupied posts in order to standardise job vacancy data for comparative purposes. EU countries must also provide data on occupied posts in order to standardise job vacancy data for comparative purposes. Where necessary, back data may be based on ‘best estimates’. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 24 June 2008. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Employment Statistics (European Commission). European rules on access to gas transmission networks European rules on access to gas transmission networks SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1775/2005 on conditions for access to the natural gas transmission networks WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules on access conditions for gas transmission networks, storage and liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities in order to contribute to customer choice in a well-functioning internal market and to long-term security of supply. KEY POINTS Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; publish daily updates of availability of short-term services (day-ahead and week-ahead) based, inter alia, on nominations, prevailing contractual commitments and regular long-term forecasts of available capacities on an annual basis for up to ten years; keep effective records of all capacity contracts and all other relevant information in relation to calculating and providing access to available capacities, to which relevant national authorities shall have access to fulfil their duties. Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; publish daily updates of availability of short-term services (day-ahead and week-ahead) based, inter alia, on nominations, prevailing contractual commitments and regular long-term forecasts of available capacities on an annual basis for up to ten years; keep effective records of all capacity contracts and all other relevant information in relation to calculating and providing access to available capacities, to which relevant national authorities shall have access to fulfil their duties. Third-party access services concerning transmission system operators Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; publish daily updates of availability of short-term services (day-ahead and week-ahead) based, inter alia, on nominations, prevailing contractual commitments and regular long-term forecasts of available capacities on an annual basis for up to ten years; keep effective records of all capacity contracts and all other relevant information in relation to calculating and providing access to available capacities, to which relevant national authorities shall have access to fulfil their duties. Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; publish daily updates of availability of short-term services (day-ahead and week-ahead) based, inter alia, on nominations, prevailing contractual commitments and regular long-term forecasts of available capacities on an annual basis for up to ten years; keep effective records of all capacity contracts and all other relevant information in relation to calculating and providing access to available capacities, to which relevant national authorities shall have access to fulfil their duties. Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; publish daily updates of availability of short-term services (day-ahead and week-ahead) based, inter alia, on nominations, prevailing contractual commitments and regular long-term forecasts of available capacities on an annual basis for up to ten years; keep effective records of all capacity contracts and all other relevant information in relation to calculating and providing access to available capacities, to which relevant national authorities shall have access to fulfil their duties. Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; publish daily updates of availability of short-term services (day-ahead and week-ahead) based, inter alia, on nominations, prevailing contractual commitments and regular long-term forecasts of available capacities on an annual basis for up to ten years; keep effective records of all capacity contracts and all other relevant information in relation to calculating and providing access to available capacities, to which relevant national authorities shall have access to fulfil their duties. Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; publish daily updates of availability of short-term services (day-ahead and week-ahead) based, inter alia, on nominations, prevailing contractual commitments and regular long-term forecasts of available capacities on an annual basis for up to ten years; keep effective records of all capacity contracts and other relevant information in relation to calculating and providing access to available capacities, to which relevant national authorities shall have access to fulfil their duties. Transmission system operators must: make public detailed information regarding the services it offers and the relevant conditions applied, together with the technical information necessary for LNG and storage facility users to gain effective access to the LNG and storage facilities. Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; publish available capacities for a period of at least 18 months ahead and shall update that information at least every month or more frequently, if new information becomes available. Transmission system operators must: make public detailed information regarding the services it offers and the relevant conditions applied, together with the technical information necessary for LNG and storage facility users to gain effective access to the LNG and storage facilities. Transmission system operators must: offer firm and interruptible services down to a minimum period of one day; make public information on contracted and available storage and LNG facility capacities on a numerical basis on a regular and rolling basis and in a user-friendly standardised manner. Transmission system operators must: make public detailed information regarding the services it offers and the relevant conditions applied, together with the technical information necessary for LNG and LNG and storage facility users to gain effective access to the LNG and storage facilities. Transmission system operators must: make public ex-ante and ex-post supply and demand information, based on nominations, forecasts and realised flows in and out of the system. Transmission system users who wish to re-sell or sublet their unused contracted capacity on the secondary market must be entitled to do so. Transmission system operators must: offer unused LNG facility and storage capacity on the primary market without delay; for storage facilities this must be at least on a day-ahead and interruptible basis; LNG and be compatible with the connected network access systems; LNG and storage facility users who wish to re-sell their contracted capacity on the secondary market must be entitled to do so. Transmission system users who wish to re-sell their contracted capacity on the secondary market must be entitled to do so. The maximum storage and LNG facility capacity must be made available to market participants, taking into account the following principles: in the event of contractual congestion: the system operator must offer unused LNG facility and storage capacity must be at least on a day-ahead and interrupt

EU statistics on migration and asylum EU statistics on migration and asylum SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1882/2003 on Community statistics on migration and asylum WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes common rules for the collection and compilation of Community statistics on: immigration to and emigration from the Member State territories, including flows from the territory of one Member State to that of another Member State and Member States must report to the European Commission (Eurostat) on the use and probable effects of estimations or other methods of adapting statistics based on national definitions to comply with the harmonised definitions. KEY POINTS EU countries must supply to the Commission (Eurostat) statistics on: immigration to and emigration from the Member State territories, including flows from the territory of one Member State to that of another Member State and Member States must report to the Commission (Eurostat) on the use and probable effects of estimations or other methods of adapting statistics based on national definitions to comply with the harmonised definitions set out in paragraph 1. EU countries must supply to the Commission (Eurostat) statistics on: persons having submitted an application for international protection or having been included in such an application as a family member during the reference period; persons who are the subject of applications for international protection under consideration by the responsible national authority at the end of the reference period; applications for international protection having been withdrawn during the reference period. EU countries must supply to the Commission (Eurostat) statistics on: the number of residence permits issued to persons who are third-country nationals, disaggregated as follows: permits issued during the reference period whereby the person is being granted permission to reside for Where the national laws and administrative practices of a Member State allow for specific categories of long-term visa or immigration status to be granted instead of residence permits, counts of such visas and grants of status are to be included in the statistics required under paragraph 1. EU countries must report to the Commission (Eurostat) on the data sources used, the reasons for the selection of these sources and the effects of the selected data sources on the quality of the statistics, and on the estimation methods used. EU countries must inform the Commission (Eurostat) without delay of revisions and corrections to the statistics supplied under this regulation, and of any changes in the methods and data sources used. EU countries must submit a report to the European Parliament and the Council on the statistics compiled pursuant to this regulation and on their quality. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 20 August 2007. BACKGROUND For more information, see: EU statistics (European Commission). Ensur Ensuring the integrity, independence, objectivity, responsibility, transparency and reliability of statutory auditors and audit firms Ensuring the integrity, independence, objectivity, responsibility, transparency and reliability of statutory auditors and audit firms Ensuring the integrity, independence, objectivity, responsibility, transparency and reliability of statutory auditors and audit firms SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 on statutory audits of statutory auditors and audit firms of public-interest entities WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? Summary 153:
Conservation of marine biological resources Conservation of marine biological resources SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 on the conservation of marine biological resources and the management of fisheries and fleets exploiting such resources WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the conservation of marine biological resources and the management of fisheries and fleets exploiting such resources. It aims to ensure that exploitation of living marine biological resources restores and maintains populations of harvested species above levels that can produce the maximum sustainable yield. KEY POINTS Scope The CFP covers the activities carried out on the territory of EU countries to which the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union applies, including by fishing vessels flying the flag of, and registered in, non-EU countries; by Union fishing vessels outside EU waters; or by nationals of EU countries, without prejudice to the primary responsibility of the flag State. The CFP applies the precautionary approach to fisheries management, and aims to ensure that exploitation of living marine biological resources restores and maintains populations of harvested species above levels which can produce the maximum sustainable yield. EU countries may cooperate with one another for the purpose of adopting measures pursuant to Articles 11, 15 and 18. Multiannual plans are adopted as a priority, based on scientific, technical and economic advice, and contain conservation measures to restore and maintain fish stocks above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield. Before measures are included in the multiannual plans, account must be taken of their likely economic and social impact. Multiannual plans may contain specific conservation objectives and measures based on the ecosystem approach in order to address the specific problems of mixed fisheries in relation to the achievement of the objectives set out in Article 2(2) for the mixture of stocks covered by the plan in cases where scientific advice indicates that increases in selectivity cannot be achieved. Where necessary, the multiannual plan may include specific alternative conservation measures, based on the ecosystem approach, for some of the stocks that it covers. EU countries may conduct pilot projects, based on the best available scientific advice and taking into account the opinions of the relevant Advisory Councils, with the aim of fully exploring all practicable methods for the avoidance, minimisation and elimination of unwanted catches in a fishery. EU fishing vessels have equal access to EU waters other than those referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3, subject to the measures adopted under Part III. EU countries may cooperate with one another for the purpose of adopting measures pursuant to Articles 11, 15 and 18. EU countries may cooperate with one another for the purpose of adopting measures pursuant to Articles 11, 15 and 18. EU countries may cooperate with one another for the purpose of adopting measures pursuant to Articles 11, 15 and 18. EU countries may cooperate with one another for the purpose of adopting measures pursuant to Articles 11, 15 and 18. EU countries may cooperate with one another for the purpose of adopting measures pursuant to Articles 11, 15 and 18. EU countries may conduct pilot projects, based on the best available scientific advice and taking into account the opinions of the Advisory Councils, with the aim of fully exploring all practicable methods for the avoidance, minimisation and elimination of unwanted catches in a fishery. EU countries may cooperate with one another for the purpose of adopting measures pursuant to Articles 11, 15 and 18. EU countries may conduct pilot projects, based on the best available scientific advice and taking into account the opinions of the Advisory Councils, with the aim of fully exploring all practicable methods for the avoidance, minimisation and elimination of unwanted catches in a fishery. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 29 December 2013 and had to become law in all EU countries by 31 December 2022. fishery and aquaculture producer organisations The common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products (CMO) is an integral part of the CFP and should contribute to achieving its objectives. It is therefore necessary to enhance their responsibilities and to provide the necessary financial support to allow them to play a more meaningful role in the day-to-day management of fisheries, whilst respecting the framework defined by objectives of the CFP and of the CMO. It is therefore necessary to enhance their responsibilities and to provide the necessary financial support to allow them to play a more meaningful role in the day-to-day management of fisheries, whilst respecting the framework defined by objectives of the CFP and of the CMO. It is therefore necessary to enhance their responsibilities and to provide the necessary financial support to allow them to play a more meaningful role in the day-to-day management of fisheries, whilst respecting the framework defined by objectives of the CFP and of the CMO. The common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products (CMO) is an integral part of the CFP and should contribute to achieving its objectives. It is therefore necessary to enhance their responsibilities and to provide the necessary financial support to allow them to play a more meaningful role in the day-to-day management of fisheries, whilst respecting the framework defined by objectives of the CFP and of the CMO. It is also necessary to ensure that their members carry out fishing and aquaculture activities in a sustainable manner, improve the placing on the market of products, collect information on aquaculture and improve their incomes. It is possible for competent national authorities to take responsibility for the implementation of those objectives, working closely with producer organisations on management issues, including, where appropriate, the allocation of quotas and the management of fishing effort, depending on the needs of each particular, the allocation of quotas and the management of fishing effort. It is also necessary to maintain the link between individual coastal communities and the fisheries and waters that they have historically exploited is respected. The unpredictability of fishing activities makes it appropriate to set up a mechanism for storing fishery products for human consumption with a view to fostering greater market stability and increasing the return on products, in particular by creating added value.

Settlement settlement system (CSD) securities settlement system (CSD) securities settlement system (CSD) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on securities settlement system WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down a number of uniform obligations to be imposed on market participants regarding certain aspects of the settlement cycle and discipline and to provide a set of common requirements for CSDs operating securities settlement systems. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to the settlement of all financial instruments and activities of CSDs unless otherwise specified in this regulation. CSDs, which have access to the funds of those bodies and which are not a separate entity, may themselves provide a number of services, such as: Core services of central securities depositories; Initial recording of securities in a book-entry system (‘notary service’); Operating a securities settlement system (‘settlement service’); Non-banking-type ancillary services of CSDs that do not entail credit or liquidity risks; Services provided by CSDs that contribute to enhancing the safety, efficiency and transparency of the securities markets, which may include but are not restricted to: Core services of central securities depositories; Operating a securities settlement system (‘settlement service’); Services related to the settlement service, such as: Organising a securities lending mechanism, as agent among participants of a securities settlement system; Providing collateral management services, as agent for participants in a securities settlement system; Settlement matching, instruction routing, trade confirmation, trade verification. DATE OF ENTRY INTO FORCE The regulation applies from 1 January 2023 to transferable securities issued after that date and from 1 January 2025 to all transferable securities. CSDs, which have access to the funds of those bodies and which are not a separate entity, may themselves provide services, such as: Core services of central securities depositories; Initial recording of securities in a book-entry system (‘notary service’); Operating a securities settlement system (‘settlement service’); Non-banking-type ancillary services of CSDs that do not entail credit or liquidity risks; Services provided by CSDs that contribute to enhancing the safety, efficiency and transparency of the securities markets, which may include but are not restricted to: Core services of central securities depositories; Initial recording of securities in a book-entry system (‘notary service’); Operating a securities settlement system (‘settlement service’); Services related to the settlement service, such as: Organising a securities lending mechanism, as agent among participants of a securities settlement system; Providing collateral management services, as agent for participants in a securities settlement system; Settlement matching, instruction routing, trade confirmation, trade verification. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 17 September 2014. BACKGROUND For more information, see: CSDs (European Securities and Markets Authority). European of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) European of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 — common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. KEY POINTS The ERDF contributes to the financing of support which aims to reinforce economic, social and territorial cohesion by redressing the main regional imbalances in the EU through the sustainable development and structural adjustment of regional economies, including the conversion of declining industrial regions and regions whose development is lagging behind. The ERDF supports the following activities in order to contribute to the investment priorities set out in Article 5: productive investment which contributes to creating and safeguarding sustainable jobs, through direct aid for investment in SMEs; productive investment, irrespective of the size of the enterprise concerned, which contributes to the investment priorities set out in points (1) and (4) of Article 5, and under the European territorial cooperation goal, the ERDF may also support the sharing of facilities and human resources, and all types of infrastructure across borders in all regions. The ERDF does not support: the decommissioning or the construction of nuclear power stations; investment to achieve the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from activities listed in Annex I to Directive 2003/87/EC; the manufacturing, processing and marketing of tobacco and tobacco products; undertakings in difficulty, as defined under Union State aid rules; investment in airport infrastructure unless related to environmental protection or accompanied by investment necessary to mitigate or reduce its negative environmental impact. The ERDF does not support: the decommissioning or the construction of nuclear power stations; the manufacturing, processing and marketing of tobacco and tobacco products; undertakings in difficulty, as defined under Union State aid rules; investment in airport infrastructure unless related to environmental protection or accompanied by investment necessary to mitigate or reduce its negative environmental impact. Summary 158:
European territorial cooperation (EGTC) European territorial cooperation (EGTC) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1301/2013 on the European Regional Development Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the European territorial cooperation goal (ESDP), the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund (Cohesion Fund), the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). It also lays down the provisions necessary to ensure effective implementation, monitoring, financial management and control of operational programmes under the European territorial cooperation goal (ESDP), including when third countries participate in such cooperation programmes. KEY POINTS The European territorial cooperation goal (ESDP) is to contribute to reducing disparities between the levels of development of the various regions and to reducing the backwardness of the least favoured regions, among which particular attention is to be paid to rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, and regions which suffer from severe and permanent natural or demographic handicaps such as the northernmost regions with very low population density and island, cross-border and mountain regions. The aim of the ESDP is to contribute to reducing disparities between the levels of development of the various regions and to reducing the backwardness of the least favoured regions, among which particular attention is to be paid to rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, and regions which suffer from severe and permanent natural or demographic handicaps such as the northernmost regions with very low population density and island, cross-border and mountain regions. The aim of the ESDP is to contribute to reducing disparities between the levels of development of the various regions and to reducing the backwardness of the least favoured regions, among which particular attention is to be paid to rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, and regions which suffer from severe and permanent natural or demographic handicaps such as the northernmost regions with very low population density and island, cross-border and mountain regions. The ESDP also contributes to promoting social and economic stability in the regions concerned, in particular through actions to promote cohesion between communities. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2014. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European territorial cooperation (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) No 1301/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1083/2006 (OJ L 210, 31.7.2006, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 1301/2013 have been incorporated in the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. European energy infrastructure priority corridors and areas of common interest Trans-European energy infrastructure priority corridors and areas of common interest SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 347/2013 on the timely development and interoperability of priority corridors and areas of trans-European energy infrastructure WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down guidelines for the timely development and interoperability of priority corridors and areas of trans-European energy infrastructure (TEN-E)*. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the criteria for projects of common interest (e.g. electricity transmission and storage, gas transmission, storage and liquefied or compressed natural gas infrastructure, smart grids, electricity highways, carbon dioxide transport and oil infrastructure). These criteria apply to projects falling within specific energy infrastructure categories: for electricity transmission and storage projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II.1(a) to (d), the project is to contribute significantly to at least one of the following specific criteria: market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; competition and system flexibility; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II.1 to 3, the criteria listed in this Article shall be assessed in accordance with the indicators set out in Annex IV. Each group determines its assessment method on the basis of the aggregated contribution to the criteria referred to in paragraph 2; this assessment leads to a ranking of projects for internal use of the group. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration to: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; competition and system flexibility; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II.1 to 3, the criteria listed in this Article shall be assessed in accordance with the indicators set out in Annex IV.2 to 5. Each group determines its assessment method on the basis of the aggregated contribution to the criteria referred to in paragraph 2; this assessment leads to a ranking of projects for internal use of the group. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration to: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; competition and system flexibility; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration to: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration to: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration to: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; competition and system flexibility; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; competition and system flexibility; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; competition and system flexibility; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; competition and system flexibility; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and reducing energy infrastructure bottlenecks; competition and system flexibility; for projects falling under the energy infrastructure categories set out in Annex II. By 31 March of each year following the year of inclusion of a project of a project of a project of common interest on the Union list, each group must give due consideration: the urgency of each proposed project in order to meet the EU energy policy targets of market integration, inter alia through lifting the isolation of at least one EU country and competition and system flexibility; for projects involving peripheral EU countries; the number of EU countries affected by each project, whilst ensuring equal opportunities for projects involving peripheral

Online online dispute resolution (ODR) Online online dispute resolution (ODR) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 524/2013 on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes (Regulation on consumer ODR) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to set up a European online dispute resolution (ODR) platform for disputes arising from the sale of goods or provision of services across the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to out-of-court resolution of disputes between consumers resident in the EU and a trader established in the EU through the intervention of an ADR entity listed in accordance with Article 20(2) of Directive 2013/11/EU and which involves the use of the ODR platform. It also applies to out-of-court resolution of disputes between consumers resident in the EU and a trader established in the EU through the intervention of an ADR entity listed in accordance with Article 20(2) of Directive 2013/11/EU and which involves the use of the ODR platform. EU countries must ensure that ADR entities, the centres of the European Consumer Centres Network, the competent authorities defined in Article 18(1) of Directive 2013/11/EU, and, where appropriate, the bodies designated in accordance with Article 14(2) of Directive 2013/11/EU, provide an electronic link to the ODR platform on their websites and, if the offer is made by e-mail, in that e-mail. EU countries must encourage consumer associations and business associations to provide an electronic link to the website of the ODR platform. EU countries must ensure that ADR entities, the centres of the European Consumer Centres Network, the competent authorities defined in Article 18(1) of Directive 2013/11/EU, and, where appropriate, the bodies designated in accordance with Article 14(2) of Directive 2013/11/EU, provide an electronic link to the ODR platform on their websites and, if the offer is made by e-mail, in that e-mail. EU EU EU statistics on the carriage of goods by road EU statistics on the carriage of goods by road SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 223/2011 — statistics on the carriage of goods by road WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out EU statistics on the carriage of goods by road. KEY POINTS Scope Each EU country must compile statistics for the EU on the carriage of goods by road by means of goods road transport vehicles which are registered in that EU country, and on the journeys made by such vehicles. The regulation does not apply to: goods road transport vehicles whose authorised weight or dimensions exceed the limits normally permitted in the EU countries concerned; agricultural vehicles, military vehicles and vehicles belonging to central or local public administrations, with the exception of goods road transport vehicles belonging to public undertakings, and in particular railway undertakings. The regulation does not apply to: goods road transport vehicles whose authorised weight or dimensions exceed the limits normally permitted in the EU countries concerned; agricultural vehicles, military vehicles and vehicles belonging to central or local public administrations, with the exception of goods road transport vehicles belonging to public undertakings, and in particular railway undertakings. The regulation does not apply to: goods road transport vehicles whose authorised weight or dimensions exceed the limits normally permitted in the EU countries concerned; agricultural vehicles, military vehicles and vehicles belonging to central or local public administrations, with the exception of goods road transport vehicles belonging to central or in particular railway undertakings. The regulation does not apply to Malta, so long as long as the number of Maltese-registered goods road transport vehicles licensed to engage in the international carriage of goods by road does not exceed 400 vehicles. Summary 164:
EU of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters EU of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1348/2000 on the service in the Member States of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve and expedite the transmission and service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters between the Member States of the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The regulation applies in civil and commercial matters where a judicial or extrajudicial document has to be transmitted from one Member State to another for service there. It does not extend in particular to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). Each Member State designates the public officers, authorities or other persons, hereinafter referred to as ‘transmitting agencies’, competent for the transmission of judicial or extrajudicial documents to be served in another Member State. The regulation does not apply to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). The regulation does not extend in particular to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). Each Member State designates a central body responsible for: supplying information to the transmitting agencies; seeking solutions to any difficulties which may arise during transmission of documents for service; forwarding, in exceptional cases, at the request of a transmitting agency, a request for service to the competent receiving agency. Each Member State designates the public officers, authorities or other persons, hereinafter referred to as ‘receiving agencies’, competent for the receipt of judicial or extrajudicial documents from another Member State. The regulation does not apply to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). The regulation does not apply to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). The regulation does not apply to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). The regulation does not apply to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). Advanced therapy medicinal products Advanced therapy medicinal products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1394/2007 on the authorisation, supervision and pharmacovigilance of advanced therapy medicinal products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down specific rules concerning the authorisation, supervision and pharmacovigilance of advanced therapy medicinal products*, which are intended to be placed on the market in EU countries and either prepared industrially or manufactured by a method involving an industrial process, in accordance with the general scope of the EU pharmaceutical legislation laid down in Title II of Directive 2001/83/EC. KEY POINTS The regulation lays down specific rules concerning the authorisation, supervision and pharmacovigilance of advanced therapy medicinal products, which are intended to be placed on the market in EU countries and either prepared industrially or manufactured by a method involving an industrial process, in accordance with the general scope of the EU pharmaceutical legislation laid down in Title II of Directive 2001/83/EC. Advanced therapy medicinal products which are prepared on a non-routine basis according to specific quality standards, and used within the same Member State in a hospital under the exclusive professional responsibility of a medical practitioner, in order to comply with an individual medical prescription for a custom-made product for an individual patient, should be excluded from the scope of this regulation whilst at the same time ensuring that relevant Community rules related to quality and safety are not a medical practitioner, in order to comply with an individual medical prescription for a custom-made product for an individual patient, should be excluded from the scope of this regulation whilst at the same time ensuring that relevant Community rules related to quality and safety are not undermined. It establishes common technical requirements for the type approval of motor vehicles (vehicles) and replacement parts, such as replacement pollution control devices, with regard to their emissions. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to the control of gaseous and particulate pollutants, useful life of emission control devices, conformity of in-service vehicles/engines and on-board diagnostic (OBD) systems of all motor vehicles, and to engines as specified in Article 1 with the exception of those vehicles of category M1, N1, N2 and M2 for which type-approval has been granted under Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 (24). Market market surveillance and control of products from non-EU countries Market surveillance and control of products from non-EU countries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 478/2008 on the organisation and operation of accreditation of conformity assessment bodies performing conformity assessment activities WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules on the organisation and operation of accreditation of conformity assessment bodies performing conformity assessment activities. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a framework for the market surveillance of products to ensure that those products fulfil requirements providing a high level of protection of public interests, such as health and safety in general, health and safety at the workplace, the protection of consumers, protection of the environment and security. The regulation applies to accreditation, used on a compulsory or voluntary basis, relating to conformity assessment, whether that assessment is compulsory or not, and irrespective of the legal status of the body performing the accreditation. National accreditation bodies are not allowed to operate across national borders, within the territory of another EU country, either at the request of a conformity assessment body in the circumstances set out in Article 7(1) or, if they are asked to do so by a national accreditation body in accordance with Article 7(3) of the regulation, in cooperation with the national accreditation body of that EU country. National accreditation bodies are not allowed to operate across national borders, within the territory of another EU country, either at the request of a conformity assessment body in the circumstances set out in Article 7(1) or, if they are asked to do so by a national accreditation body in accordance with Article 7(3) of the regulation, in cooperation with the national accreditation body of that EU country. Rights rights of rail passengers Rights of rail passengers SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1380/2007 on the rights of rail passengers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the rights of rail passengers in the European Union (EU) by ensuring that they have the same rights as other EU citizens. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway companies. Statistics Statistics Statistics on education, training and lifelong learning Statistics on education, training and lifelong learning SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 996/2008 on the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of education and lifelong learning WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics in the field of education and lifelong learning. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to the production of statistics in three domains: education and training systems; education and training systems; and participation of adults in lifelong learning. It covers all domestic educational activities regardless of ownership of, or sponsorship by, the institutions concerned (whether public or private, national or foreign) and of the education delivery mechanism. The data collection covers all student types and age groups. Subjects covered Data are collected on: students’ enrolment, including the characteristics of the students; entrants; graduates and graduations; education expenditure; educational personnel; foreign languages learnt; class sizes; allowing the calculation of indicators on the inputs, processes and outputs of the education and training systems. The data collection covers all domestic educational activities regardless of ownership of, or sponsorship by, the institutions concerned (whether public or private, national or foreign) and of the education delivery mechanism. Correspondingly, the coverage of the data collections extends to all student types and age groups. The data collection must be collected on a voluntary basis as explanatory variables useful for further analysis of the participants and non-participants’ profiles. The data sources and sample size must be established on the basis of precision requirements that shall not require effective national sample sizes to be larger than 5 000 individuals, calculated on the assumption of simple random sampling. Statistics Statistics statistics in the EU Energy statistics in the EU SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 322/97 establishing a common framework for the production, transmission, evaluation and dissemination of comparable energy statistics in the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common framework for the production, transmission, evaluation and dissemination of comparable energy statistics in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a common framework for the production, transmission, evaluation and dissemination of comparable energy statistics in the EU. It lays down detailed rules concerning the reporting of the data needed for the national statistics by undertakings and other sources. They are transmitted with the following frequencies: annual, for the energy statistics in Annex B; monthly, for the energy statistics in Annex C; short-term monthly, for the energy statistics in Annex D. The data to be forwarded and the applicable clarifications or definitions of the technical terms used are provided in the individual Annexes. Every reasonable effort must be undertaken to ensure coherence between energy data declared in accordance with Annex B and data declared in accordance with Commission Decision 2005/166/EC of 10 February 2005 laying down the rules for implementing Decision No 280/2004/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning a mechanism for monitoring Community greenhouse gas emissions and for implementing the Kyoto Protocol (12). Every 5 years, EU countries shall provide the Commission (Eurostat) with a report on the quality of the data transmitted as well as any methodological changes that have been made. REFERENCES Act Entry into force Deadline for transposition in the Member States Official Journal Regulation (EC) No 322/97 of 17 February 1997 establishing a common framework for the production, transmission, evaluation and dissemination of comparable energy statistics in the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
