Rights rights in the bus and coach transport Rights of passengers in the bus and coach transport SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 181/2011 on the rights of passengers in bus and coach transport WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the rights of passengers in the bus and coach transport sector in the European Union (EU). It aims to improve the rights of passengers in the bus and coach transport sector in the EU. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to passengers travelling with regular services for non-specified categories of passengers where the initial boarding point or the final alighting point of the passenger is situated in the territory of an EU country and where the scheduled distance of the service is 250 km or more. The regulation applies to passengers travelling with regular services for non-specified categories of passengers where the initial boarding point or the final alighting point of the passenger is situated in the territory of an EU country and where the scheduled distance of the service is 250 km or more. The regulation does not affect the rights of passengers under Directive 90/314/EEC and shall not apply in case where a package tour referred to in that directive is cancelled for reasons other than cancellation of a regular service. The regulation does not apply to passengers with open tickets as long as the time of departure is not specified, except for passengers holding a travel pass or a season ticket. The regulation applies to passengers travelling with occasional services where the initial boarding point or the final alighting point of the passenger is situated in the territory of an EU country and where the scheduled distance of the service is 250 km or more. The regulation does not apply to passengers travelling with regular services for non-specified categories of passengers where the initial boarding point or the final alighting point of the passenger is situated in the territory of an EU country and where the scheduled distance of the service is 250 km or more. The regulation does not affect the rights of passengers under Directive 90/314/EEC and shall not apply in case where a package tour referred to in that directive is cancelled for reasons other than cancellation of a regular service. Aquaculture statistics Aquaculture statistics SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1882/2003 on Community statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the obligations of EU countries to submit to the European Commission statistics on all the aquaculture activities conducted in freshwater and saltwaters on their territory. KEY POINTS EU countries must use surveys or other statistically validated methods covering at least 90 % of the total production by volume, or by number for the production of hatcheries and nurseries. EU countries must identify the production by species. However, the production of those species which individually do not exceed 500 tonnes and do not represent more than 5 % in weight of the production by volume in a EU country may be estimated and aggregated. EU countries must use surveys or other statistically validated methods covering at least 90 % of the total production by volume, or by number for the production of hatcheries and nurseries. Use of sources other than surveys is subject to provision of an ex-post assessment of the statistical quality of those sources. EU countries must use surveys or other statistically validated methods covering at least 90 % of the total production by volume, or by number for the production of hatcheries and nurseries. EU countries must identify the production by species. However, the production of those species which individually do not exceed 500 tonnes and do not represent more than 5 % in weight of the production by volume in a EU country may be estimated and aggregated. Use of sources other than surveys is subject to provision of an ex-post assessment of the statistical quality of those sources. A EU country having a total annual production of less than 1 000 tonnes may submit summary data estimating the total production. EU countries must identify the production by species. However, the production of those species which individually do not exceed 500 tonnes and do not represent more than 5 % in weight of the production by volume in a EU country may be estimated and aggregated. Use of sources other than surveys is subject to provision of an ex-post assessment of the statistical quality of those sources. EU countries must use surveys or other statistically validated methods covering at least 90 % of the total production by volume, or by number for the production of hatcheries and nurseries. EU countries must use surveys or other statistically validated methods covering at least 90 % of the total production by volume, or by number for the production of hatcheries and nurseries. EU countries must use surveys or other statistically validated methods covering at least 90 % of the total production by volume, or by number for the production of hatcheries and nurseries. Use of sources other than surveys is subject to provision of an ex-post assessment of the statistical quality of those sources. EU countries must use surveys or other statistically validated methods covering at least 90 % of the total production by volume, or by number for the production of hatcheries and nurseries, without prejudice to paragraph 4. Summary 175:
North control and enforcement scheme North-East Atlantic fisheries control and enforcement scheme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 on the application of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Control and Enforcement Scheme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the general rules and conditions for the application of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Control and Enforcement Scheme (NEAFC), which came into force on 1 May 2007. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all EU vessels used or intended for use for fishing activities carried out in respect of fishery resources in the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Regulatory Area (NERA), which lies beyond the waters under the fisheries jurisdiction of the parties to the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC). EU countries must send to the European Commission, in a computer-readable form, a list of all vessels flying their flag and registered in the EU which are authorised to fish in the Regulatory Area, in particular the vessels authorised to fish directly for one or more regulated resources together with any amendments to the list. This information must be sent no later than 15 December each year or no later than 5 days before the vessel enters the Regulatory Area, in particular the vessels authorised to fish directly for one or more regulated resources together with any amendments to the list. EU countries must ensure that gear used by their fishing vessels in the Regulatory Area is marked in accordance with Commission Regulation (EC) No 356/2005 of 1 March 2005 laying down detailed rules for the marking and identification of passive fishing gear and beam trawls (8). EU countries must ensure that gear used by their fishing vessels in the Regulatory Area is marked in accordance with Commission Regulation (EC) No 1005/2008 of 29 September 2008 establishing a Community system to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. EU countries must report to the Commission or the body designated by it by 15 February each year on the status of the proceedings concerning infringements of the conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC which were committed during the previous calendar year. Reporting and follow-up EU countries must report to the Commission or the body designated by it on the status of the proceedings concerning infringements of the conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC which were committed during the previous calendar year. Reporting and follow-up EU countries must report to the Commission or the body designated by it by 15 February each year on the status of the proceedings concerning infringements of the conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC which were committed during the previous calendar year. Reporting and follow-up EU countries must report to the Commission or the body designated by it on the status of the proceedings concerning infringements of the conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC which were committed during the previous calendar year. Reporting and follow-up EU countries must report to the Commission or the body designated by it on the status of the proceedings concerning infringements of the conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC which were committed during the previous calendar year. Reporting and follow-up EU countries must report to the Commission or the body designated by it must report to the NEAFC on the status of the proceedings concerning infringements of the conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC which were committed during the previous year. Reporting and follow-up EU countries must report to the Commission or the body designated by it must report to the NEAFC on the status of the proceedings concerning infringements of the conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC which were committed during the previous year. Reporting and follow-up EU countries must report to the Commission or to the body designated by it must report to the NEAFC on the status of the proceedings concerning infringements of the conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC which were committed during the previous year. Ecolabel scheme EU Ecolabel scheme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1980/2000 on the establishment and application of the voluntary EU Ecolabel scheme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules for the establishment and application of the voluntary EU Ecolabel (EU Ecolabel) scheme. It is part of the sustainable consumption and production policy of the EU, which aims at reducing the negative impact of consumption and production on the environment, health, climate and natural resources. It is part of the sustainable consumption and production policy of the EU, which aims at reducing the negative impact of consumption and production on the setting of ecodesign requirements for energy related products. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to any goods or services which are supplied for distribution, consumption or use on the EU market whether in return for payment or free of charge (hereinafter ‘products’). It does not apply to medicinal products for human use, as defined in Directive 2001/83/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 November 2001 on the Community code relating to medicinal products for human use (8), or for veterinary use, as defined in Directive 2001/82/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 November 2001 on the Community code relating to veterinary medicinal products (9), nor to any type of medical device. The regulation does not apply to food and feed products, as defined in Directive 2001/83/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 November 2001 on the Community code relating to medicinal products for human use (8), or for veterinary use, as defined in Directive 2001/82/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 November 2001 on the Community code relating to veterinary medicinal products (9), nor to any type of medical device. Protection protection for medicinal products Protection for medicinal products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1901/2006 on the granting of a supplementary protection certificate for medicinal products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the conditions for granting a supplementary protection certificate* for medicinal products. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to medicinal products which have been granted marketing authorisation in the European Union (EU) for a period of 5 years. The protection granted by the certificate is limited to the product covered by the authorisation to place the product on the market and for any use of the product as a medicinal product that has been authorised before the expiry of the certificate. The application for a certificate must be lodged within 6 months of the date on which the authorisation to place the product on the market was granted. The application for an extension of the duration may be made when lodging the application for a certificate or when the application for the certificate is pending and the appropriate requirements of Article 8(1)(d) or Article 8(2), respectively, are fulfilled. The application for an extension of the duration may be made when lodging the application for a certificate or when the application for the certificate is pending and the appropriate requirements of Article 8(1)(d) or Article 8(2), respectively, are fulfilled. The application for an extension of the duration may be made when lodging the application for a certificate or when the application for the certificate is pending and the appropriate requirements of Article 8(1)(d) or Article 8(2), respectively, are fulfilled. Convention Convention Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters SUMMARY OF: Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters Decision (EU) 2017/625/JHA on the conclusion of the Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE CONVENTION AND OF THE DECISION? The convention aims to protect the interests of natural persons, rights in property arising out of a matrimonial relationship, wills and succession, bankruptcy, proceedings relating to the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions and analogous proceedings, social security and arbitration.
